number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												This is my first playing a Bioware game ever and hearing the popularity of Bioware in recent years of its story and characters I had to check it out, and what better way they manage to create in their early works and my favorite franchise, Star wars!Story I will try sum it up as much possible without any major spoilers, the story is average good I’m sorry to say I can’t be wow by the plot which I will explain later in more details, but the main plot is interesting don’t get me wrong. The light vs. dark side I should say is cliché but there are some story telling that is pretty surprisingly interesting picking up half way through the game. 	I chose to be light side because I’m always am and got motivated to defeat Malak the antagonist of the game. There are some nice moments where you go “awe” and “what” and that’s good, it shows Bioware was starting to stable themselves as the “capital ship” of 3rd party company.However, their earliest isn’t much what I expected because the backstory of the old Republic never mention this ever and even talks about the origin of the war. Yes they do talk about the rise of the Sith but just a brief one, I was expected a prequel of the star wars movies about telling the origin of what happen about everything; the war, the rise of Sith, the origin of the Republic everything, but no not a whole lot and both side doesn’t show much color. The Sith are so generic with their “I’m a snob so that means everyone I look is a weakling” their motivation of doing this to so weak to me, yes they do what Sith do but what they are doing just doesn’t convince me to show sympathy to them or even see them differently. Is just “he’s bad and we’re good.” What about the republic surely they are some goody-two shoes? Well at first almost but no they can be somewhat corruptive and wrong of their morals too! And that’s what I want from it, the republic side showing its own “both side” but also want the Sith to show “their two faces as well” instead of all being rich snob Nazis. A final note on this yes they do some moments with the Sith on Korriban but not entirely enough to see them as “they are evil but I can see their side point why they do this horrid things.”Charactersthe NPC and partners are interesting as well especially I like that when you got the time you can talk to them and hear some back stories even if you bring one of them along in one certain planet, more dialogue options to choose and you will have a good backstory of the character. Malak I think is a cool villain especially the way he talks plus and robo-jaw that he has is really cool to look at.Now here comes the problems I have this game and two things are repetitive and cliché for the story aspect side. The NPC of any species just looks the same especially on the human side they have the same texture face model which doesn’t add a lot of emersion seing the same human character twice and even the voice, the alien sort of get a pass but their voice over just doesn't because they reuse the same alien language dialouge many times and it gets tired around the ears. Yes, I know that Bioware was at their first steps and you could say is budget problem by not hiring more actors and having to change face textures about everything that won’t affect too much on the rating scale, is just a nitpick problem where you try to discover a new world with new species (though in my case I already know the species) but they sound the same you wanted to see many new variation looks/voice as possible. Hopefully in the second game when the game got very popular it will have more.Choose your sideAlright now the big one and is, which side would you choose, well I should say, none of it matters! Well what I meant was it really doesn’t matter in “morality,” yes of course you still choose your light and dark ending but at endgame, for the rest of the game it really doesn’t matter if you are the lightest person in the world, you can still choose the dark path at the end of the game. So what gives? What is the objective of those light side dark side points? Is really for gameplay wise in armor and weapons, the force powers I made my main character have some dark powers even some of my light-side partners, which doesn’t really matter if you are good or not you can still equip dark powers or light powers if you are choosing your endings. Another thing about the moral points is just cosmetic option but only in the dark path when your character begins to change color. So now it sounds like it only effects gameplay and not story telling which blows badly right? Well at first yes, I thought it would be the biggest disappointment ever since no matter if you are the biggest jerk in this galaxy or the nicest one you can switch sides in matter of seconds. Well I should say not entirely in that center problem, because you can still have consequence when doing certain side quest and do evil things and in some planets some characters will pay you back hard, if you are prepare.No, I think the big point taker has to be your partners’ reaction to the player’s action. Yes they say “you did a wrong thing” but they never “punish” you for it or better yet leave you or stop you even though they are the once that help you do the main’s dirty deed. Most of your partners are from the light side and whatever you do will make them react but not upon action which is really shame. I expect during some quests or the main “dialogue” choice your friends will abandon you and you will be recruit with more dark players and the story switch to another quest, “conquest” I thought. You can be the biggest jerk without a reason to them and they won’t even leave your side no matter what you did, even by the next set of choice that you made “wrong” you can switch to being nice again and they will forget about your “dirty deeds.” I find it odd that after everything I do bad they won’t bat an eye of my behavior which just tells me that my choice won’t affect much around me until the very end, but during the whole game experience I thought choosing one side might affect the story telling as two sides, one fight for the good or join the Sith and fight from the republic and you will eventually fight Yoda! (Which I know that isn’t him.) My main when going dark or light doesn’t give a deeper meaning why he’s doing it, I’m just having that express feeling that “I do it because I’m a bully and want to take things just because,” “I’m good because I’m a goodie two-shoes,” and mind you I’m talking about story wise, the gameplay well that is different because I want the extra status boost.The side missions some I like but is just another generic “do this because is the right thing to do and do this because you are a jerk” Even the options you choose sounds a bit preachy for me thinking “well duh of course is bad to do this but should I?” There is only one side quest I think is my favorite where it involve no light or dark side points and only pure morality choice which about there I got a moral dilemma and I wish there was more like that but I know if it is it makes the system even more pointless.Verdict: The final verdict is a 7/10 a good starting game for Bioware’s time but need improvement on the writing, and moral choice but other than that I did enjoy the game despite some minor flaws the gameplay works flawlessly and I don’t have much of a problem to say, hopefully when I finish star war kotor 2 maybe things will change and improve until then, may the force be with you.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												A true classic, KOTOR has more role-playing than any other BioWare game.  It was also their first serious attempt at character development and more immersive storytelling, and is thus greatly improved in these areas over their earlier games although not quite up to par with Dragon Age and Mass Effect.The gameplay is heavily D&D inspired and while it is more complex and tactical than any modern mainstream RPG, it lacks in some areas compared to the Neverwinter Nights games and even Dragon Age: Origins.  For one, there is no point-and-click movement, which means you can only control one party member at a time in combat.  This is very, very limiting from a tactical point of view.  You can't, for example, have two scoundrels simultaneously sneak up on people to deliver stealth attacks at the same time.  The camera is also third-person only which is better than isometric only but not as good as having the best of both worlds like the aforementioned titles.KOTOR is surprisingly fluid though, not clunky like many would expect due to its age.  Getting widescreen to work is a very annoying process, one could only hope it gets the same treatment from Aspyr as its sequel.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												Now 13 years old, the affectionately nicknamed Kotor is still worth playing. Sure the menus are clunky and textures show their seams from time to time, but the meat of the game, the plot and the character development, is still fresh. The story arc, like with the original Star Wars trilogy, is better if you've managed to avoid key spoilers. Even knowing what's going to happen doesn't stop the journey there from being wonderful because the main plot is secondary to the events happening on the planets involved in it anyway. In true Star Wars fashion, the mission at hand has our heroes hopping from one planet to the next and each layover is focused around getting entangled in the goings-on of that place and its people rather than moving the plot forward.  Captions are a necessity as some speak in their native tongues, further driving home the fact that the galaxy doesn't revolve around you as the player. The world and its people feel alive, though the lack of player accommodation can get a bit tiresome.The world of Kotor may not be an 'open-world', but with a seedy card game-based gambling ring, a struggling racing circuit, and plenty of side quests, there are too many distractions to call it linear either. The same can be said for the physical act of playing the game as well. Straightforward violence with all its lightsaber dueling, blaster shooting, and Force pushing is always an option, and though it is a fantastic spectacle of parring and dodging, the fun of it wears out quickly. Thankfully, a number of encounters can be bypassed with a clever application of a character's skills. Computers can be hacked to shut down security systems, derelict droids can be repaired only to be sent against their former masters, and enemies can be persuaded to disband before a conflict even arises. For a game that was designed with the original Xbox in mind, there is a surprising amount of freedom in how the game is played.  That freedom is echoed in the game's approach to the player character's companions. Though only two can be chosen to leave the ship at any time, they all hang around and level up either way, meaning the dynamic can be altered to suit a situation as it arises. Simply talking to your companions can reveal a good portion of their character, but it's the personal quest each companion has that acts as their turning point. How players react during a personal quest will affect their compatriots for better or worse, providing some bit of control over their personalities, and giving the player the option of role-playing with the group dynamic in addition to their own created character. At its core, Kotor is about a group of heroes struggling against the dark side of the Force while traveling through hyperspace and interacting with a wide variety of alien species, just like any good Star Wars episode. But Kotor offers more than just lightsabers and blasters, and it never loses sight of the legacy it's adding to.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												One of the best Star Wars licence game ever made and one of the best RPG games of all time. Period.There's little to be said about this masterpiece. Even being a 12 year old game, it didn't age too badly and still plays fantastically. Possible to launch it in 1080p with a bit of tinkering. Game is fairly unstable on modern OS and in one playthrough crashed about 7 or 8 times. Still, all technical negatives aside the game still feels wonderfully crafted. Endless dialogs, various quests, different and varied locations and choices with serious consequences - all these elements are only a small part of the whole KOTOR package. HK-47 is probably one of the best video characters BioWare has ever made, or even in general. Game does have it's flaws. For example: inventory system is really basic and once you start hitting 20-30+ hours into the game, and if you're a hoarder, it gets very difficult to find stuff that you need, since everything is thrown into one pile. Camera can take some getting used to, but overall won't be too much of a trouble. AI pathing is poor, ofter will your AI partners get stuck and you'll have to take control of them to make them move towards you again. Also your AI doesn't use health packs, stimulants, or any other consumable, half the time they don't even use their learned abilities. There is a "Script" option, but it's very basic, since you can't customize it, and it only offers 3 rudimentary options. Some of the above mentioned negatives are more or less nitpicks, since this is technically a turn-based RPG, so you are encouraged to micromanage everything yourself, rather than let the AI do everything for you. This might be a deal breaker for some, but I personally did not find it too difficult to setup fights with my party, while also controlling my own character. Game does have a pause, so you can always pause and take a breather if things are getting out of hand.As a 12 year old RPG game, it puts most today's RPG to shame with what it has to offer.A must have game for any RPG, Star Wars fan, or even if you just like great games.meatbag/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												If you ever wondered where games like Mass Effect or Dragon Age came from, then sit down, my child, and let me tell you of a game called KOTOR. This game is one of the best, all-time Western RPGs. Yeah, it's showing its age compared to more modern RPGs. Yeah, the combat system is clunky and easy to exploit (the AI's pathing is awful). Yeah, the graphics aren't the great thing they were back in the early 2000s. But the real heart of this game is the story and characters. It was one of the first games of its kind and wasn't afraid to take risks, paying homage to the old Star Wars trilogy while creating its own interesting universe and characters. I had this game as a kid on my old Dell (it was piece of junk) like ten years ago and I thought this game was the♥♥♥♥♥♥back then. Basically, you play as a Jedi trying to stop the Sith from destroying the Republic. You can use the Force to bring unholy destruction on the dirty non-Jedi plebes or even just use blasters, because lightsabers are for the weak.Generally, the choices go between being the nicest guy (or lady!) in the galaxy, or being a total♥♥♥♥♥♥ But there's a lot of good writing you don't see in a lot of modern video games. Especially from your companions (9 of them in total). I'm able to get it running on my MSI laptop w/Windows 10, so I'm not sure the difficulty others are having. I disabled movies and it works just fine (you're not missing out on anything essential with the movies). Also, get Flawless Widescreen from somewhere in the internets if you have a large monitor, it helps a bunch with some of the visual glitches users run into. If this game comes on sale and you like Star Wars or RPGs, definitely consider buying it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												Now, 12 years since its release, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic still stands as one of the finest games ever wrought by the hands of BioWare, long before they were corrupted by the Sith Lord Darth Riccitiello and turned to the dark side.KotOR is a classic RPG with honest-to-god stats and skill points, an increasingly rare sight in these, the days of merciless streamlining. The graphics are obviously dated (but not an eyesore), and the combat finds a comfortable balance between simplicity and the necessity of pausing to issue commands to your party.To fans of the Star Wars franchise, the world of the Old Republic will be familiar, but also incredibly alien. Unsurprisingly, the writing is clumsy by modern standards, equal parts railroading and patronizing handholding. You get the sense that each line of dialogue was written to leave an opening for every question you can ask, and characters have no problem imparting upon you the same piece of information a dozen times over the course of a conversation. In spite of this, however, the world makes it incredibly easy to immerse yourself in it. Even with its shortcomings, KotOR is undeniably the genesis of the modern RPG, the proto-Mass Effect, and although you might not get it on with 100 year-old blue aliens, you can't help but feel that this is where it all began.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												 Ignore my low Steam hours, I played this hours on end on the original Xbox port and then on a disc version for PC. This game is incredible. Even if you aren't much of a Star Wars fan or fan of the Extended Universe, I still recommend this game. This was the original game by the great Bioware, and so when you are playing it you might think to yourself "Hey, this is a lot like Mass Effect!" Pros:+++Great Story-I have to say this is one of the most well written stories in a video game ever, in my opinion. Don't let anyone spoil the story for you.  One of the greatest plot twists ever! ++Non-linear gameplay-You choose what planet you go to and in what order in the story.++Great and Memorable Characters-Anyone who has played this game knows how interesting and memorable the characters are; not one person could forget Carth or Bastila.++Fun Turn-Based Gameplay-Very reminiscent of Tabletop RPG's mechanic wise.+Interesting Locations-Some planets return from the movies, but their are plenty of new ones to keep you interested, from a Sith planet haunted by the ghosts of Sith Lords long passed to a planet entirely of water with a few cities here and there.Cons:-Somewhat slow start-Beginning of the game can get quite redundant after a few playthroughs, but still has enough to keep you interested and having fun.-Shows its age graphically-There are mods to fix this, however.Ultimately I give it a 9.9/10. A great experience.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Here is my review of Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic.As a huge Star wars fan it surprises me that it took me so long to play this game. I recently picked it up in the steam christmas sale for like 3 bucks. I played a couple days later to see how good it actually was. to be honest at first I absolutely hated it. the combat style was completely new to me and I had no idea about anything in the old republic era of star wars so I closd the game and didn't play it for another month. I opened it back up convinced that this game was something. I mean most people say that this is the greatest Star wars game ever, let alone rpg ever.I beat this game a couple hours ago and I have to say that this has been the best Star Wars game I have ever played in my life. Number one this game has an insane amount of content in it. I beat the main storyline in about 30 hours. Most games that hae come out recently don't have a storyline this long. The characters in this game are absolutely awesome to learn about and get to know through the game. the game incorporates a kind of moral system where decisions you make in the game effect whether you go to the dark side and go to the light side. This game has a very cool combat system (was you get the hang of it.) It is turn based so most people (at least me) was not used to this type of system. The graphics are very dated yes, but the game is by far playable. I honestly didn't really have a problem with them. But the best part of the game is that it feels completely "star wars" I really did feel as if I was imersed in the world of Star Wars.Now for cons of this game. In my opinion there isn't that many cons. The only ones I can think of is that your "bag" i guess or where you hold items in endless you can hold a million items if you wanted to which is cool but the items aren't very organized which is the con in this case. My other con is that after I beat the game I planned on doing all of the leftover side quests but when I beat it just rolled credits and I wasn't allowed to go back and do other things in the game which kind of annoyed me.My final rating of this game would have to be 10/10.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												You know, every couple years you have one "pearl" in every kind of genre. 2003, BioWare and Obsidian gave us "Knights of the Old Republic" or short: "KotoR"And this game IS absolutly amazing. WARNING: May include spoilers, even though I´ll do my best to keep them out.KotoR plays like 4000 years BBY (for not SW Nerds: Battle Before Yavin, or 4000 years before "A New Hope").Darth Revan and Darth Malak, two heros of the Mandalorian war, a war that could´ve destroyed the Republic, return to the galaxy as new Dark Lord of the Sith. Darth Revan, the leader of the newly "build" Sith army wins one battle after the other, before he´s betrayed by his student Darth Malak, who wants to rule on his own. Now that we know a little bit about this games backstory (which is also included in the game and one central point of the plot), let´s get down to the mainstory.You´re a soldier (or one of two other classes), recruited for duty on the "Endar Spire". While you´re resting, the Endar Spire gets hijacked by the Sith army. You try to fight your way trough the enemy, while you do your best to reach the Jedi "Bastila Shan", an important role in this war because of her "Force Meditation". As you´re unable to find her, you make an emergency landing on the planet "Taris", which is confronted with a sith blockade. On Taris you´re trying to find Bastila and afterwards leave this planet. As soon as you found her (after doing some favors and a veeery terrible first 2-3 hours), you leave Taris and travel to "Dantooine". As soon as you arrive, your Jedi-Training starts and a long journey to save the galaxy begins...Even though KotoR is already 11 years old, it still has some good graphics to offer. Surely there are so animations that look kinda strange or even some textures which look "washed-out", but it´s still a pretty game. You travel to different planets, which all have their individual look. As we´ve seen in BioWares "Dragon Age 2", this isn´t something they´re always able to achive ;) Also, some of the characters faces look kinda mechanic. They have a disturbing lack of emotions, espacially your main character. Yet they´re able to eradicate this by having absolutly professional voice actors. The atmosphere created by a very typical Star Wars score, pretty graphics and  very well written (and spoken) dialogues is intense and believable, espacially as you´re reaching the end. Planets like "Kashyyk" create their own unique flair and are very well translated from the source-material. Especially the dialogues do a good job of delivering story, feels and atmosphere and serve a very wide variaty of emotions. But as we all know, that´s something BioWare has mastered over the years. The character editor is also nice. Even though you don´t have that much influence on the appearance (as you can only decide how your character looks by some different faces, without having much influence on them), but you´re able to build a charater you want through the variaty of stats and attributs. A good and fair skill-system keeps you motivated to level up and the (even though it´s very limited) customization of your weapons will enable you to create a very individual character. I won´t say much about the story, but.. it´s absolutly amazing. I finish this game at least once a year (also KotoR II: TSL, which in my opinion is a little bit better, even though it´s an unfinished game) and I´m still enjoying it. It keeps you motivated to go on, find all this different NPC´s and involves you in a story that (at it´s time) was a amazing thing for the SW franchise. I recommend you to buy this game and enjoy it. I´ratte it with an 8.6/10. It´s a classic. It´s an example for BioWares brilliance. Buy it now and you will have 20 hours of fun in a world that wants to be explored!

												Oh my god, this game is awesome! At first, it kept crashing during cinematics, but running it in windowed mode will fix that. This game's quite old, so it's also harder: it doesn't autosave frequently and dying will force you to load a save up to 30 minutes ago (so always save!). If you get past these minor issues, the game's absolutely wonderful. It's increadibly immersive with great character development and story progression. It's nonlinear, so you can have a different experience everytime you play. I've only played through it once so far and I loved it. KOTOR's got a feature that's missing from a lot of todays games, but I can't really tell what that is. If you're a Star Wars fan, this is a must play!

content:
Posted: July 15, 2012
												KOTOR (as the cool kids call it) is; put simply; a classic. If you've enjoyed newer BioWare titles such as Mass Effect and Dragon Age, you will enjoy Knights of the Old Republic. Following a battle system very similar to Dragon Age, KOTOR puts you in the shoes of a force sensitive character trying to survive, find his (or her) place in the universe, and deciding between the call of the light side or the pull of the dark side. Of course you've got to save the universe somewhere along the way.This game shines in always giving you the option to CHOOSE how to do things. Will you help that troubled person, or destroy them? Will you show charity, or rob the helpless of what little they have? Whether you are a Star Wars fan or not, this is a must play. Very few games give you an experience like this.The gameplay is no slouch either, with deep customization, party choices, and force powers to train and use. If you're a fan of RPGs, Star Wars, or video games in general, get this!

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												Rating 7.5/10Overview: Turn Based RPGThe Good+ The game has a lot of robust options in how you build your character. You start by choosing between 3 classes, soldier, scout or scoundrel. Each class obviously focuses on different aspects of combat. Further in the game you can then choose the Jedi you wish to be: Guardian, Consular or Sentinel. You can fully customize your character how you wish between attributes, skills, feats and jedi powers. All of this leads to many different options and replaybility in how you design your character+The core aspect of the game is that as you can either play as a Jedi that is good or evil. Saving people, being kind and choosing the peaceful solution leads you to the light side while doing the opposite leads you to the darkside. Doing so leads to certain bonuses to your Jedi Powers. Being good means Lightside powers will use less mana and darkside powers cost more and viceversa. I find the system to be very effective because it ties morality choices into gameplay, a feature that seems to be very lacking in today's modern games. +The game supports a solid story that is engaging throughout the entire game. Dialogue is well done although a bit heavy on exposition in the beginning. +As is the case with every Bioware game, the supporting cast of characters are interesting and unique and features some of the best writing in the game. Getting to know your companions and there back stories is one of the highlights of the game. +The game has plenty of interesting sidequests that are fun to play and depending on how you solve them really start to shape your character. I wish there was more ambiguity with the quests because it becomes very obvious which is the good and evil way to solve them. A moral grey area would have made choices tougher to make.+ The game takes place across a series of planets within the Star Wars universe. Each location feels different from the last and has a rich back story that just adds to the authenticity. The AverageCombat in the game is basic, simply select your choice of attack then watch and hope your character can actually connect with a hit. It doesn't feel very engaging especially in the later parts of the game when you become really powerful. The game had many graphical glitches and bugs in certain areas that made it difficult to play.Final boss is frustratingThere are a lot of areas in the game that feel big and empty.The BadThe UI especially navigating to find items in your inventory is a chore and frustrating. The inventory screen is a long list of your items. Finding a specific item can be problematic, for example, if you find a data pad and want to read it, you have to open your inventory scroll through a long list of items until you find it. If you have other datapads in your inventory that you haven't checked yet then you have to check each one until you find the one you're looking for. There are options to filter the list based on specific items but this doesn't fix the overall problem of a bad overall inventory management system. ConclusionI have played this game many times before it came on steam and having it in my library I decided to play it again to see how well it holds up and I was pleasantly surprised. This game feels like the blueprint for Mass Effect as it shares many similarities in its design choices.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												KotOR is probably my favorite game of all time, for quite a few reasons. I remember picking it up back in 2003 when I was 8, just because it had 'Star Wars' in the title. Ever since then, I have played this game through numerous times. The game regardless of how you play it, is just plain fun. The graphics are dated, yet they still look pretty decent. The gameplay is challenging and rewarding. The setting and locations in this game are stunning. From the urban cities of Taris, the deserts of Tatooine, to the oceans of Manaan, all of the locations are beautifully done. The characters you meet are diverse and likable. Most are pretty interesting, including npcs. There are plenty of opportunities to walk around and explore or talk to characters off of the beaten path. There are also mini games such as Pazaak and swoop races. The story is intriguing and has many turns. It also has a lot of replayability. There are different conversation choices, different endings, different classes, abilities, weapons, character party, and for the hardcore players no alien subtitles. There are plenty of customization options for the weapons you use, whether you want to be a calm and thoughtful Jedi using lightsabers and the force, or be the smooth talking smuggler using blasters and grenades, you are able to choose the way you want to play. In conclusion, this is probably my favorite game. It has decent graphics that have aged somewhat well. The locations, characters, and story are all well made and great. There are many options for customization and replayability. Also the game is just plain fun. I'd highly recommend it to any Star Wars, sci-fi, or rpg fan.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Just finished this game for the 1st time after seeing that it was $2.99 on the Steam Holiday sale, & it's by far one of my top 5 RPG games of all time.Pros:I love how vast the Star Wars KOTOR universe is (especially for such an old game) & how the player can steer the game in any direction that they choose since there are so many ways the game can be played.Also, the character customization is great & the story is very solid & immersive. If you're a fan of Star Wars & love RPG-type games such as the Witcher series, then I highly recommend this game.Cons:In my opinion, the ending/s of the game was a little weak. It was very short, abrupt, & unsatisfying after playing through such a deep & immersive story to say the least.Also, once you finish the story, you can no longer free roam. Instead it takes you back to the main menu where your only options are to reload previous saves or start a new game. I wasn't a fan of this since I spent so much time upgrading my character & making him look cool just to find out that you literallty can't do anything with him after completing the story.Still an amazing game though! Highly recommend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												I played through this game, it's storyline is rich and creative and backed up by some brilliant voice acting and graphics especially for a 2003 game. I will not spoil the story but it has an excellent ending and interesting plot twists which the user will not expect. It is a fantastic chapter in the Star Wars universe and I highly recommend it to any RPG fans as it truly makes the genre hard to better, again for a 12 year old game it is unbelievably addicting and will have you playing the game non-stop until you finish.It has replayable value as you get to choose your own path, light side or dark side you have the choice entirely and conversational structure in the game allows you to make these decisions.Puzzles feature heavily throughout the game and are challenging with little aid, personally I struggled with them and had to research how to solve them online but they can be easily figured out with some effort. The characters in this game are unique and loveable, they aid the protagonist throughout and help influence your decisions if you allow yourself to fall into this game's smart trap of wanting to make your companions happy so you make decisions based on their interests.Overall I would put this game into my top 5 list of games ever, and it easily has one of the best storylines of any game I've encountered as an RPG fan.

Posted: December 31, 2016
												Still a great game after all these years, there's only a few real problems I can think of:* Controls are a bit fiddly sometimes. I've gotten stuck on invisible objects, and once somehow got trapped inside a door requiring me to reload a saved game.* The underwater section in Manaan is still horrible. Prepare to spend 5-10 minutes /slowly/ walking across the sea floor while wishing horrible things upon the developers. * The inventory system is a bit of a mess. Maybe it's because I loot everything I come across, but by the end of the game finding anything was a nightmare. Just way too much stuff and not many ways to sort it. Other than that this is still a great RPG 13+ years later. The voice acting is superb and the story is the most well written out of any Star Wars media I've come across. Recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												One of BioWare's earlier achievements, KOTOR's an easy game to criticize in retrospect. From the release of Baldur's Gate in 1998 to Mass Effect just 10 years later, most every RPG released by BioWare would follow the same mass-produced, literally by-the-books Hero's Quest outline—i.e., each game’s plot felt like a meeting of forced expectations, sometimes satisfying and sometimes mind-numbing in their predicted delivery—a choice that simultaneously made their products restrictive holds against and necessary stepping stones for advancing the depth possible in video game story-telling.But who cares, right? KOTOR tells a generic Star Wars story with mostly generic Star Wars characters, meeting every generic Star Wars expectation a gamer could ask for right down to the tired, required lines, but it does so almost flawlessly, to such an extent that its seemingly pedestrian qualities make it among the most fun and accessible modern RPG experiences and Star Wars stories. In an age-old formula so noticeable and so repeated some players even refer to it as "the BioWare Cliché," a faceless variable with a background too vague and mysterious to be taken seriously, recognized by everyone around them as vitally important is thrown into the midst of a universal conflict against a threatening Force of Unfathomable Evil. As their life is turned upside down against their better judgment, they’re guided by close mentors friends, one of whose personality’s teeters on the edge of simply being Han Solo before he’s overcome by emotional turmoil (and the personality traits are thusly handed off to a snarky youngster and her wookie companion), the other a sassy, sexy Obi-Wan-Leia hybrid.* Through thick and thin, unsurprising twists and heart-wrenching betrayal, they form a series of close bonds and pass the required tests necessary to rid the galaxy of malice once and for all.Dropping the vague references to clichés repeated, KOTOR stars a young nobody, canonically male, her past just barely customizable to the point of ineffectuality, being shipped under unspoken circumstances that end under the galaxy-wide Jedi Civil War igniting her hidden potential in the Force (à la Luke Skywalker) over an introduction spent making friends and escaping the occupied planet-city Taris. Under the tutelage of these newfound friends, she hones her skills in the Force, strained physically and morally under four major tests of heroism across beloved planets like Tatooine and Kashyyk. What she and her entourage seek, they seek in the footsteps of the Sith Lord Malak and his former master Revan—deceased: betrayal, Siths, &c.**—, piecing together an alien map in order to understand what massive power source drove those two to Team Slytherin, or, like, whatever.Their fall is itself a story existing partially outside the game’s bounds, a series of events that took place after the culmination of the Mandalorian Wars—the galaxy’s previous Big Mistake and a war led by the war-mongering culture of Mandalore, a bone-headed, unlikeable civilization modeled after a single facet of humanity, their sole goal to enslave or destroy everyone just because. The backdrop of this war’s aftermath fuels the chaotic political state in KOTOR; it was a war in which the Jedi stood by, watching—idling on the decision of whether their place included interference—and yet a war won almost single-handedly the two previously-mentioned Jedi, rationalizing the need to defend freedoms and lives threatened by Mandalore’s conquest.Krayt dragons, wookie tribes, life debts, Klingons, Jawas and their sandcrawlers, planets being razed from space, half-naked old men running around star ships, limitless sources of unimaginable power, lost alien civilizations, bland villains—KOTOR has everything you expect and love from a Star Wars tale, wrapped and guided by the massive conflict of good and evil fighting over mythopoeic indulgence. The central theme of mythology itself, abused by Lucas and now by BioWare, here works as a symbol of their aging morality mechanics. Following this game, treading those grey areas became a duty, even if it took a couple stories and universes to figure out how to present believably.As an RPG born in 2003, it almost can’t help but tread that line between oldschool and new-, providing a strategic (but accessible, simplified) battle-management system that lets you plan the course of every encounter at your own pace, coupled with real-time decision-making and exciting action full of lasers and light sabers and lightning-quick force powers and, uhm, grenades, I guess—just with dice rolls, added and appreciated: beloved mechanic of chance in things past. The leveling system also stands as one of BioWare's most fluid and functional (opposed to, say, Mass Effect’s messy, meaningless overdose of options and numbers), letting players tread lines however customizable they can get to the point of breaking the game, i.e., as with many RPGs prior to this last generation, it’s not exactly difficult to customize your character to the point that whatever plot point is impassibly difficult, i.e., multiple save files are strongly suggested. And as such an RPG, it took some shocking dares in character design: HK-47, the fan-favorite assassin droid prefaces every delivered line with the emotional intent behind them, creating a stir of always-contemptuous black humor and irony; and Jolee Bindo, whose entire presence—a good man sitting comfortably on the line between the series’ Dark and Light Sides, quick to point out the flaws (and outright stupidity) inherent in the tenets of the Jedi Knight code—hints at the brilliant postmodern deconstruction Star Wars would get in Obsidian's ambitious sequel. They let us know lead-author Drew Karpshyn was capable of a lot more than farting out game-y dialogue and fetch quests by the dozens even when limited by that bullet-point list of Quest-with-a-Q requirements.That greyed-out line Jolee walks, also brings to the forefront major flaws in BioWare’s championship of the modern RPG format. Areas of grey don’t apply much outside of his character or even BioWare’s RPGs prior to Mass Effect 2, but the forceful impact of choice has been their calling card (& often selling point) since 1998. When choice arises in dialogue or action, the writers strive to bring the sense that you’re calling the shots, that you’re the acting force that shaping its conclusion. Those choices, unfortunately, amount to either following that path of charity and sacrifice defined by the Jedi code, or make your avatar sound like a cartoon jerk tossing out petty insults like candy--maniacal laugh included. Under this system, choices often amount to little more than variations on the lines “I’d love to help clothe and feed you!” or “I don’t have time for your stupid babble.” This never makes sense with whatever narrative is being told: E.g., Why would these characters follow these bad decisions? Why would this person fall in love with this monstrous cliché?Are these aged mechanics and writing a bad thing? I would definitely argue No, despite the lingering force of Internet backlash BioWare gets from more critical players. The ambition driving this illusion of meaning in player choice has only improved and grown more bewilderingly ambitious with every game BioWare’s released, the massive steps taken between each a necessary movement culminating in (as of 2013) the phenomenon that is the Mass Effect trilogy, a series driven successfully by the player choice and personal involvement all their previous RPGs like KOTOR strived towards. It may have taken a lot of trial-‘n’-error gambits—still ongoing—but it doesn’t mean the errors are necessarily mistakes, and it certainly doesn’t mean they aren’t worth experiencing when they’re this danged fun.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2012
												Seriously let me just be completely honest here. This game is amazing, but Can be a pain at times. The game itself is absolutely amazing and it has a wonderful story that any starwars fan should be enthralled by. HOWEVER! The fact remains that this game is extremely dated and it has a lot of problems when it comes to computers. It can be as I would put it "whiny" and crashes a lot for some people. The game is so outdated that it literally thinks some pc parts are older than itself or it cannot recognize them. I know many work around for this issue and they are on the forums, but it is still a pain. Beyond that, the graphics and some of the sounds are pretty iffy, but since it is 10 years old you should expect that. I would still recommend buying this game even if you wait for the steam summer/winter sales where it is 5-10 bucks. (US) It is seriously worth it even after all of the problems behind it. (Be aware that the second is even worse off with those issues for some people.)

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												This game is incredible. While it is an old game (2003), with not very impressive graphics, it boasts an incredible story, with side quests at every turn. You begin on the Endar Spire, a Republic Star Ship, which has been taken over by Sith. You, and a Republic pilot Carth, are the only survivors. You crashland in your escape pod on the planet Taris. What I find incredible about this is that it has it's own original storyline. While it has details that are the same (like Wookies and over races) it adapts them to make you have an enjoyable time while playing. I would highly recommend this game to just about anyone!It is a fully singleplayer game, however it's sequel Knights of the Old Republic 2, does have a multiplayer mode. I've only played three hours, and haveb't gotten very far into the story. Just, buy it. It's only $3.00 in the winter sale. I can guarantee that you won't be disapointed (except when there is a supposed hacker attack on Steam, and you can't acess KOTOR. That is the only time you can get understandably♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥about the game)A shout out to Potato Retrieving Master, who persuaded me to buy it. Thank you!

												It took me a while to get in to KOTOR. I tried and failed about 5 times to get into this game, and gave up on the first planet every time. It's buggy, awkwardly voice acted, and the game is dull as dishwater until you become a jedi.And then you become a jedi. That's when this game picks up. Suddenly you're tossing lightsabers all over the place, getting all up in the faces of your enemies, You turn in to some all powerful god-thing (unless you go light side consular, which I tried, and it sucks balls) and get to go to town ont he universe. I sincerely think that this game gets as good as the hype at that point.Not wanting to say too much, the story is brilliant, the villians are suitably... villanous... and the character arcs of the main characters are in keeping with the highest quality of bioware character arcs.If you've not played KOTOR, have a little patience to churn through the opening section; and enjoy role playing games then I'd recommend that you give this a go. I hope that you get as much out of it as I did.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												BUY IT!NOW!In my opinion the best Star Wars game ever made! Period!The first time i played this game was right after it's release 2003 (?)(Too lazy to look it up right now ^^).Until today it's by far my favourite game from the Star Wars franchiseand still among my top 3 (if not the best) Singleplayer RPGs. What distinguished it from the games i had played until that time wasthe freedom to actively influence the story (WHICH IS AWESOME BTW!This was made before Bioware learned the words DLC / Cliffhanger)by my decisions, the depth and difficulty of the combat system (especially on higher difficulty levels) coupled with a great party-systemas well as the the sheer content that is available(you have to play this game at least twice (light side / dak side)to get the full experience out of it, and you still will find new stuff withevery playthrough). A warning though:If you don't like turn based combat you might have trouble taking a liking to this game. Even if the combat itself can be played in real-time and doesn'tpause by itself you will constantly die if you don't hit the pause-button(which is the spacebar btw!) frequently on higher difficulties.If you can get along with turn based combat, this game will offer the bestStar Wars experience anyone could hope for, including tactical depth,awesome characters, and a story that is so well-told, no other gameuntil today was able to surpass it in that respect.

I know some RPG's you have to focus or constantly try to put yourself in the protaganist's shoes, but Knights of the Old Republic does it for you. It opens the door for you, grabs your coat, sits you down on one of the best chairs on earth, hands you a beverage created by George Lucas from up in the cantina in the sky, and tells the best story you've ever heard. Quite literally, if you haven't played this game yet, you're the equivilant of a bantha fodder. Don't know what is? Even more of a reason to play this game. What are you waiting for? Just buy it. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												I played through this game, it's storyline is rich and creative and backed up by some brilliant voice acting and graphics especially for a 2003 game. I will not spoil the story but it has an excellent ending and interesting plot twists which the user will not expect. It is a fantastic chapter in the Star Wars universe and I highly recommend it to any RPG fans as it truly makes the genre hard to better, again for a 12 year old game it is unbelievably addicting and will have you playing the game non-stop until you finish.It has replayable value as you get to choose your own path, light side or dark side you have the choice entirely and conversational structure in the game allows you to make these decisions.Puzzles feature heavily throughout the game and are challenging with little aid, personally I struggled with them and had to research how to solve them online but they can be easily figured out with some effort. The characters in this game are unique and loveable, they aid the protagonist throughout and help influence your decisions if you allow yourself to fall into this game's smart trap of wanting to make your companions happy so you make decisions based on their interests.Overall I would put this game into my top 5 list of games ever, and it easily has one of the best storylines of any game I've encountered as an RPG fan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Good story hampered by clumsy mechanics is the simplest way to sum up KOTOR. Having played this again recently I was struck by how terrible the D20 style ruleset is for a Star Wars game. The force is a mysterious energy field, supposedly binding and connecting all living beings. Except sith troopers apparently, who will resist force push at DC 14 unless your wisdom is over 20. Reducing the force powers to simply "wizard spells" is greatly at odds with the narrative of Star Wars and the game suffers for it. This game is the standard Bioware plot (tm). You have a rag-tag band of heroes and villains, you have 4 totally different places to visit each containing a quarter of the plot device and you can be good, evil or slightly sarcastic. Despite the copy paste plot and characters Bioware somehow crammed a lot of Star Wars moments into this game, it also amazingly has a plot twist to rival ESB which was superbly executed. Another hugely annoying aspect is having 9 allies and yet you can only ever adventure with two, leaving most of the team hanging out on the ship. For all its flaws this is still a game worth playing, especially as it sets up the masterpiece that is the sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												I will always remember the first time Jolee Bindo told me the 'boy and the snake' story. It was a perfect bit of writing, ending with my very dodgy-looking Jedi (pale skin, yellowing eyes, red lightsaber) asking him, 'Am I supposed to be the snake?' He says, 'Well now, that's what I came to find out'.--KotOR is mostly an interactive story, and a really magical one. The writing is slightly dated by the standards set by Bioware's more recent hits, often slightly 'videogame-y' and always less cinematic than the likes of Mass Effect, but it's still just amazing. The combat is semi-turn based - very similar to Dragon Age: Origins or the recent Pillars of Eternity - but it's a lot of fun. And if you've ever wanted to play a game where Bioware absolutely live up to their promises and potential for once, then this is it. It's the one that put them on the map.It's also the game to play if you're looking for that 'feel like you're in Star Wars' quality that games like Battlefront and Jedi Knight come so close to capturing but don't quite get. In an average 30-40 hour playthrough of KotOR you can expect to save / condemn the galaxy, ride swoop bikes, manipulate beaurocats and dodge docking fees with the Jedi mind trick, leap halfway across a map to cut sand-people in half, convert a lost dark Jedi back to the light (or the opposite), buy an assassin droid who calmly tells you how every single one of his former owners died by his hands and just how much he enjoyed it, and argue with all manner of space-Nazis about every facet of space-racism. It feels very 'Star Wars' and very 'Bioware' at the same time, but the two never clash.What the game does best is in breathing life and weight into the 'good versus evil' meter that so many RPGs had back then, and some still maintain shadows of (i.e. Mass Effect, The Walking Dead). KotOR's devs and writers were aware that they had the Star Wars licence for this one and that their story was supposed to be about Jedi knights. They took full advantage of the 'lure of the dark side' angle, allowing the cruelty or generosity of your actions to be meaningful and to form the centre of a game's story and theme. Who your character becomes is crucial to the plot, so deciding who to torture with lightning and who to donate money to makes all the difference in the world. It all builds up to a single brilliant decision and two very distinct, very satisfying endings. The game knows exactly what was so great about Star Wars and The Empire Strikes Back (Vader, Yoda, the hero's journey, the dark side, the Falcon, the love story, the big twist, the world-building, the witty banter) and it lovingly packs it all in.--A polished, large, joyful Star Wars replica. It gets everything 'just right'.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												This game is incredible. While it is an old game (2003), with not very impressive graphics, it boasts an incredible story, with side quests at every turn. You begin on the Endar Spire, a Republic Star Ship, which has been taken over by Sith. You, and a Republic pilot Carth, are the only survivors. You crashland in your escape pod on the planet Taris. What I find incredible about this is that it has it's own original storyline. While it has details that are the same (like Wookies and over races) it adapts them to make you have an enjoyable time while playing. I would highly recommend this game to just about anyone!It is a fully singleplayer game, however it's sequel Knights of the Old Republic 2, does have a multiplayer mode. I've only played three hours, and haveb't gotten very far into the story. Just, buy it. It's only $3.00 in the winter sale. I can guarantee that you won't be disapointed (except when there is a supposed hacker attack on Steam, and you can't acess KOTOR. That is the only time you can get understandably♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥about the game)A shout out to Potato Retrieving Master, who persuaded me to buy it. Thank you!

												Still a great game after all these years, there's only a few real problems I can think of:* Controls are a bit fiddly sometimes. I've gotten stuck on invisible objects, and once somehow got trapped inside a door requiring me to reload a saved game.* The underwater section in Manaan is still horrible. Prepare to spend 5-10 minutes /slowly/ walking across the sea floor while wishing horrible things upon the developers. * The inventory system is a bit of a mess. Maybe it's because I loot everything I come across, but by the end of the game finding anything was a nightmare. Just way too much stuff and not many ways to sort it. Other than that this is still a great RPG 13+ years later. The voice acting is superb and the story is the most well written out of any Star Wars media I've come across. Recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												One of BioWare's earlier achievements, KOTOR's an easy game to criticize in retrospect. From the release of Baldur's Gate in 1998 to Mass Effect just 10 years later, most every RPG released by BioWare would follow the same mass-produced, literally by-the-books Hero's Quest outline—i.e., each game’s plot felt like a meeting of forced expectations, sometimes satisfying and sometimes mind-numbing in their predicted delivery—a choice that simultaneously made their products restrictive holds against and necessary stepping stones for advancing the depth possible in video game story-telling.But who cares, right? KOTOR tells a generic Star Wars story with mostly generic Star Wars characters, meeting every generic Star Wars expectation a gamer could ask for right down to the tired, required lines, but it does so almost flawlessly, to such an extent that its seemingly pedestrian qualities make it among the most fun and accessible modern RPG experiences and Star Wars stories. In an age-old formula so noticeable and so repeated some players even refer to it as "the BioWare Cliché," a faceless variable with a background too vague and mysterious to be taken seriously, recognized by everyone around them as vitally important is thrown into the midst of a universal conflict against a threatening Force of Unfathomable Evil. As their life is turned upside down against their better judgment, they’re guided by close mentors friends, one of whose personality’s teeters on the edge of simply being Han Solo before he’s overcome by emotional turmoil (and the personality traits are thusly handed off to a snarky youngster and her wookie companion), the other a sassy, sexy Obi-Wan-Leia hybrid.* Through thick and thin, unsurprising twists and heart-wrenching betrayal, they form a series of close bonds and pass the required tests necessary to rid the galaxy of malice once and for all.Dropping the vague references to clichés repeated, KOTOR stars a young nobody, canonically male, her past just barely customizable to the point of ineffectuality, being shipped under unspoken circumstances that end under the galaxy-wide Jedi Civil War igniting her hidden potential in the Force (à la Luke Skywalker) over an introduction spent making friends and escaping the occupied planet-city Taris. Under the tutelage of these newfound friends, she hones her skills in the Force, strained physically and morally under four major tests of heroism across beloved planets like Tatooine and Kashyyk. What she and her entourage seek, they seek in the footsteps of the Sith Lord Malak and his former master Revan—deceased: betrayal, Siths, &c.**—, piecing together an alien map in order to understand what massive power source drove those two to Team Slytherin, or, like, whatever.Their fall is itself a story existing partially outside the game’s bounds, a series of events that took place after the culmination of the Mandalorian Wars—the galaxy’s previous Big Mistake and a war led by the war-mongering culture of Mandalore, a bone-headed, unlikeable civilization modeled after a single facet of humanity, their sole goal to enslave or destroy everyone just because. The backdrop of this war’s aftermath fuels the chaotic political state in KOTOR; it was a war in which the Jedi stood by, watching—idling on the decision of whether their place included interference—and yet a war won almost single-handedly the two previously-mentioned Jedi, rationalizing the need to defend freedoms and lives threatened by Mandalore’s conquest.Krayt dragons, wookie tribes, life debts, Klingons, Jawas and their sandcrawlers, planets being razed from space, half-naked old men running around star ships, limitless sources of unimaginable power, lost alien civilizations, bland villains—KOTOR has everything you expect and love from a Star Wars tale, wrapped and guided by the massive conflict of good and evil fighting over mythopoeic indulgence. The central theme of mythology itself, abused by Lucas and now by BioWare, here works as a symbol of their aging morality mechanics. Following this game, treading those grey areas became a duty, even if it took a couple stories and universes to figure out how to present believably.As an RPG born in 2003, it almost can’t help but tread that line between oldschool and new-, providing a strategic (but accessible, simplified) battle-management system that lets you plan the course of every encounter at your own pace, coupled with real-time decision-making and exciting action full of lasers and light sabers and lightning-quick force powers and, uhm, grenades, I guess—just with dice rolls, added and appreciated: beloved mechanic of chance in things past. The leveling system also stands as one of BioWare's most fluid and functional (opposed to, say, Mass Effect’s messy, meaningless overdose of options and numbers), letting players tread lines however customizable they can get to the point of breaking the game, i.e., as with many RPGs prior to this last generation, it’s not exactly difficult to customize your character to the point that whatever plot point is impassibly difficult, i.e., multiple save files are strongly suggested. And as such an RPG, it took some shocking dares in character design: HK-47, the fan-favorite assassin droid prefaces every delivered line with the emotional intent behind them, creating a stir of always-contemptuous black humor and irony; and Jolee Bindo, whose entire presence—a good man sitting comfortably on the line between the series’ Dark and Light Sides, quick to point out the flaws (and outright stupidity) inherent in the tenets of the Jedi Knight code—hints at the brilliant postmodern deconstruction Star Wars would get in Obsidian's ambitious sequel. They let us know lead-author Drew Karpshyn was capable of a lot more than farting out game-y dialogue and fetch quests by the dozens even when limited by that bullet-point list of Quest-with-a-Q requirements.That greyed-out line Jolee walks, also brings to the forefront major flaws in BioWare’s championship of the modern RPG format. Areas of grey don’t apply much outside of his character or even BioWare’s RPGs prior to Mass Effect 2, but the forceful impact of choice has been their calling card (& often selling point) since 1998. When choice arises in dialogue or action, the writers strive to bring the sense that you’re calling the shots, that you’re the acting force that shaping its conclusion. Those choices, unfortunately, amount to either following that path of charity and sacrifice defined by the Jedi code, or make your avatar sound like a cartoon jerk tossing out petty insults like candy--maniacal laugh included. Under this system, choices often amount to little more than variations on the lines “I’d love to help clothe and feed you!” or “I don’t have time for your stupid babble.” This never makes sense with whatever narrative is being told: E.g., Why would these characters follow these bad decisions? Why would this person fall in love with this monstrous cliché?Are these aged mechanics and writing a bad thing? I would definitely argue No, despite the lingering force of Internet backlash BioWare gets from more critical players. The ambition driving this illusion of meaning in player choice has only improved and grown more bewilderingly ambitious with every game BioWare’s released, the massive steps taken between each a necessary movement culminating in (as of 2013) the phenomenon that is the Mass Effect trilogy, a series driven successfully by the player choice and personal involvement all their previous RPGs like KOTOR strived towards. It may have taken a lot of trial-‘n’-error gambits—still ongoing—but it doesn’t mean the errors are necessarily mistakes, and it certainly doesn’t mean they aren’t worth experiencing when they’re this danged fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2012
												Hands down, one of the best RPGs available for PC or Mac. Bioware (already renown for Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights) took the Star Wars universe and did it justice; proving it could make for a damn fine game. Whether you're a Star Wars fan or just a fan of the RPG genre, KOTOR is every bit worth owning.PROS:+Good amount of customization for protagonist and team members.+Choice between Light Side and Dark Side with every decision made within the story.+Huge, open-world exploration spanning multiple planets.+Non-linear story; both in terms of moral choices and the effects of some side missions.+Some cool mini-games, from Swoop racing to Pazaak (card game). +Endless REPLAY VALUE.CONS:-6th gen (PS2 era) graphics will annoy graphics snobs.-No multiplayer.-No Steam Achievements (yet).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. When this game released many moons ago I was a young teenager. I have never played an RPG before and even worse: I did not know this game was an RPG. Unaware of my ignorance I placed the game into the the disc tray of my Xbox and never looked back. Since the release of the game I have over 1000 hours of play time between the Xbox and PC version. But what makes this game so good?Firstly is the the story. From the first second you feel a level of immersion that I find hard to get with other games. What makes the story even more enjoyable is that each playthrough you can do things differently and experience something new.Character customization has almost everything I could want in a game. While there are restrictions with physical appearance in character creation everything else seems to disregard it. The leveling system is beautiful with enough options that ensure every character you create will be different if you try. I find myself being immersed with the Equip screen as well, sometimes going through my equipment just to see what I will look in various armors/robes.The gameplay itself is satisfying. Using a real time turn based combat system, you rarely feel things are moving slow. While in combat you have the ability to pause the game, if you wish, and issue up four commands for your companions to perform. Experimenting with this can be fun to see what type of damage you can do and how quickly you can kill harder opponents.Overall, I would highly recommend this game for any Star Wars or RPG fan. Knights of the Old Republic is a milestone in gaming and everyone should try to experience what it hast to offer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Spent all my time negging Mission and Bastila while they fought over me.10/10 would neg again.Jk (sort of). In all seriousness though. this has to be one of the greatest games ever made, a fact most major gaming publications have agreed upon. I played it many years ago, but never finished. Now I've returned to the KOTOR universe, and I can't see myself not finishing it this time around.The gameplay is very strategic and smart. It's addictive no matter your success rate. When you dominate in combat, you want to continue dominating. When you fail, success usually seems so close that you want to try again until you've won. The same can be said of the mini-games... I've put way more time into Pazaak than I care to admit.However, it's the character development where the game really shines. The slow build towards making significant changes in the Star Wars universe captures the tone and feel of A New Hope way better than most other Staw Wars tie-ins. Most of the voice acting is incredibly strong and reasonably paced. It was actually a pleasure to listen to the voice work, which is a must in a game with this much dialogue.With a little elbow grease (digitally speaking, of course) you can mod your way to a truly incredible experience. Some of the hi-res textures out there really help modernize the title. There are many, many other gameplay enhancements to be downloaded too, although I've been trying to keep my experience as close to the original as possible.To that point, I was able to use Pinnacle Profiler to configure my 360 gamepad to play close to the original X-Box version, with a shift mode controlling the mouse pointer when I need it. Again, it took some toying and learning, but I was able to get it to the point where it works extremely well.Not all is sunny and roses on the planet Taris, though. There are some odd graphical glitches from time to time. Also, some of the NPC's faces repeat or are similar enough to be jarring. In 8 hours of play with a few mods installed, I only experienced one crash to desktop (and of course, this could be related to having modded the files). There was also an annoying glitch in which my character would stop moving after battles, but this was fixed on my machine by enabling V-Sync.However, the overall quality of the title is so absurdly high that these minor annoyances pale in comparison.HIghest recommendations on this one. Do yourself a favor and enjoy this masterpiece classic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												It's a solid dungeons and dragons game masquerading as star wars. The base system for this game is quite obviously D20 from character creation to combat.I'll cut straight to my main gripe which admittedly comes from my expectations compared to reality. Not only do blasters have nowhere near the impact they had in the movies (and they retain their clumsy and random nature) but also everyone has swords. At first this is confusing, but when you replace blaster with bow in your mind it starts to make sense. That's because weapon statlines are straight out of D20 analogues. Mechanically this is fine because it creates some balance between melee and ranged, but thematically it just ruins the experience when you just want to blast some thugs and move along.That is not to say that the star wars paintjob is bad: the story and characters are great! I just was dissapointed with how the game played. I recommend it if you're desperate for a star wars RPG and can put up with the combat. I've enjoyed it, but only despite the gameplay rather than for it.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Honestly the only reason you should get this on PC over the Xbox version is for the consistent framerate.  It just feels better with a controller and unfortunately the PC version doesn't natively support controllers nor will binding keyboard keys to a custom controller set up alleviate that issue.  This is a great game, It has interesting characters, good progression, a decent amount of non-linear play, and fulfilling side missions, With all that said it's just not as great as I wish it was on the PC version.  I've heard from many that they can't stand the PC version, but I got used to it.  I even managed to play this game on my laptop while in bed using my touchpad because I'm filled with sin.

												By far my favorite RPG of all time. Quite literally now when I play an RPG I hold it up to the standards of this game, which isn't usually a good idea because this game isn't easy to beat. I still enjoy playing through it again and again, it just doesn't get old. The story is so filling, it's hard not to get drawn into it. I know some RPG's you have to focus or constantly try to put yourself in the protaganist's shoes, but Knights of the Old Republic does it for you. It opens the door for you, grabs your coat, sits you down on one of the best chairs on earth, hands you a beverage created by George Lucas from up in the cantina in the sky, and tells the best story you've ever heard. Quite literally, if you haven't played this game yet, you're the equivilant of a bantha fodder. Don't know what is? Even more of a reason to play this game. What are you waiting for? Just buy it. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												Played a lot before steam was really a thing, so +80~ hours.This is the best Star Wars licence game in existence. Story is deep and rich, gameplay is succinct and accessible. Also (with the exception of the final boss) this game gives the most options I've ever seen to the "Scoundrel" class. Talking your way out of things and finding alternatives to force and combat will be almost constant as the scoundrel, provided you've focused your progression correctly.This will seem very similar to old school "Neverwinter Nights" but with significantly improved presentation and balance.Some compatibility issues may arise, most appear to be fixable, this game is simply VERY old so it's to be expected.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												BUY IT!NOW!In my opinion the best Star Wars game ever made! Period!The first time i played this game was right after it's release 2003 (?)(Too lazy to look it up right now ^^).Until today it's by far my favourite game from the Star Wars franchiseand still among my top 3 (if not the best) Singleplayer RPGs. What distinguished it from the games i had played until that time wasthe freedom to actively influence the story (WHICH IS AWESOME BTW!This was made before Bioware learned the words DLC / Cliffhanger)by my decisions, the depth and difficulty of the combat system (especially on higher difficulty levels) coupled with a great party-systemas well as the the sheer content that is available(you have to play this game at least twice (light side / dak side)to get the full experience out of it, and you still will find new stuff withevery playthrough). A warning though:If you don't like turn based combat you might have trouble taking a liking to this game. Even if the combat itself can be played in real-time and doesn'tpause by itself you will constantly die if you don't hit the pause-button(which is the spacebar btw!) frequently on higher difficulties.If you can get along with turn based combat, this game will offer the bestStar Wars experience anyone could hope for, including tactical depth,awesome characters, and a story that is so well-told, no other gameuntil today was able to surpass it in that respect.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Just finished this game for the 1st time after seeing that it was $2.99 on the Steam Holiday sale, & it's by far one of my top 5 RPG games of all time.Pros:I love how vast the Star Wars KOTOR universe is (especially for such an old game) & how the player can steer the game in any direction that they choose since there are so many ways the game can be played.Also, the character customization is great & the story is very solid & immersive. If you're a fan of Star Wars & love RPG-type games such as the Witcher series, then I highly recommend this game.Cons:In my opinion, the ending/s of the game was a little weak. It was very short, abrupt, & unsatisfying after playing through such a deep & immersive story to say the least.Also, once you finish the story, you can no longer free roam. Instead it takes you back to the main menu where your only options are to reload previous saves or start a new game. I wasn't a fan of this since I spent so much time upgrading my character & making him look cool just to find out that you literallty can't do anything with him after completing the story.Still an amazing game though! Highly recommend.

												Synashi here to tell you about Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic.  From the esteemed developer, BioWare, this game sets the story around 4,000 years before Episode IV.  The Republic is under attack from fallen war heroes.  You play a soldier of dubious background, whose role in the plot is far greater than first implied.  Turn-based, party oriented combat, a powerful story, and a sense of humor make this game a must have!  If you don't believe me, why not take into consideration that it was 2003's Game of the Year?Rating: 9/10

All in all, if you are a fan of well-done RPG's or Star Wars, this is an absolute must.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Pretty cool game. I didn't get to play this game around the time it came out so the graphics are a bit dated for me. But the rpg elements are nice, you get to customize your stats (like str, dex, int, etc.), skills (like opening doors, repairing droids, etc.), and feats (which are actions you can do in combat or passives that gives bonus). If you don't want to do all that customizing, you can just auto allocate them in the options. Some items, like armour, lightsabers, and other weapons, are customizable that will increase damage or add effects like a chance to stun your enemy.The story, which is probably why you're here, is pretty good. Side missions are good. You get to choose your conversations when interacting with npcs, some of them can make a difference in the story while others doesn't. Just a warning though, there is a lot of talking in this game and if you try to choose every possible conversation, some of the npcs will just repeat the same information that you got from other npcs.Overall, this♥♥♥♥♥♥is good. If you're an rpg fan and doesn't mind dated graphics and long conversations, this ♥♥♥♥♥ is for you. I give this game a thumbs up, as you can see up top.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												I avoided STAR WARS - Knights of the Old Republic (SWKotOR) for a long time. Long used to WASD gaming it has an unusual but fitting control system that you quickly get used to. I freely admit learning it was the only part of the game that wasn't smooth, and even saying that it's very quick to get used to.Not long into SWKotOR I began to realise and regret that I didn't play it sooner. As a long-time STAR WARS fan, and with how much I enjoyed STAR WARS Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy & STAR WARS Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast on release date because of how well-made they were I should've known how good SWKotOR would be.Even now I'm surprised with how well-written the game was. I couldn't stop playing it, couldn't wait to see how the relationships with the other characters would unfold, couldn't wait to get started on the next side quest.The only gripe I had at all was that it was short - slowly pushing 100% of content played only took me a little over 40 hours.After you get to grips with the different controls you're going to love it if you're a STAR WARS fan of any kind.SWKotOR is an old, but superb game.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												KOTOR. Motha♥♥♥♥ING KOTOR. This game my middle school life bearable, even if I didn't make it off of Taris half the time.First, the negatives. This game will crash. A lot. It was originally for XBOX classic, so compatibility issues run amok on this game. Not so much for the sequal for some reason. Next, your teammate AI is equivalent to a 5-year-old when it comes to enemies, especially if they just come out of combat. If there's a herd of kathak hounds 20 yards out and they're about to die, they're gonna jog the distance and let off a few rounds before it occurs to them they might bleed to death before they pull a trigger any more. The graphics are kinda cruddy, but again, it was made for XBOX classic, so notm uch you can do to help that. As for positives, the lore is a nice bit of fun to sink your teeth in to if you're into that (I know I am), and if you set the difficulty right for your level of badassery, the game can be challenging and fun in it's combat. the skills allow you to tackle problems a multitude of ways, as are expected, but the persuade skill becomes moot fairly quickly when you become a jedi and get access to the force persuade ability.In summation, if you're willing to fight through a few crashes and some crummy graphics, and you're a fan of Bioware RPGs, I recommend it.
