content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												I would say that aged badly. But it's still playable if you can survive the atrocious screen resolution (it won't go higher than 1024x768, but you can make it Full HD with Flaweless Widescreen). Talking about the game itself, it's pretty good, I love all the party characters, they're deep and have a good development, some more than others. The story is pretty decent and easy to follow even if you have no clue about the Star Wars universe. The setting is convincing, you have a lot of things to do and the NPCs are very interesting. The combat on the other hand is kinda old school, from a time where dice rolls were a thing (they're still a thing in some other games), so don't come expecting a "Mass Effect combat" like I did, but it's decent if you know your way around the character creation. Don't be afraid to use guides and manuals. I could just don't recommend this game after all the frustration I had with it, but in the end, that's impossible. KOTOR is still a very good game and one I'm glad I played until the very end, against all odds.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2012
												Statement: The RPG that made Bioware famous to non-PC gamers may have one of the most spoiled game stories ever. Spoilers are why I didn't finish for 9 years, and much like ESB, the impact is less if you know ahead of time. But KOTOR isn't just one of the first great Western console RPGs.Explanation: In 2003, two Star Wars prequels & The Matrix Reloaded left many dejected. This was the blockbuster people WANTED. There had been Star Wars games before, but here was a setting wholly untouched by George Lucas. Though much is evocative of the original films, many of the NPCs are rough drafts for Mass Effect's.Observation: The setting hides many of Bioware's now-maligned shortcomings; here the binary morality makes sense. The "Bioware romance" can't really come into full effect either. But sci-fi trappings aside it's literally D&D for all the clunkiness that entails. I grew up on Baldur's Gate, so I can deal.Conclusion: The assassin droid HK-47 is the greatest. Play for him, meatbags!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												To start of with, Knights of the Old Republic is my 2nd favourite game, along with KOTOR 2.The storyline is just... epic. I love how this game makes you learn bit by bit "the truth", until the final revelation. I also liked the characters, and if any of your companions annoy you, it's your choice if you want to bring them in your adventures or not. And the weapons... whoa. At the end of the game, I had like 30 different weapons (lightsabres, swords, heavy blaster rifles, blaster pistols, etc.) and lots of equippable stuff like armour, energy shields or cybernetic implants. But the dark side/light side alignment system is an even greater feature. Depending on your actions and what you say, your character will either gain light side points or dark side points. So choose your words carefully, they can change the whole game.SpoilersWARNING There is one single spoiler that can ruin the whole game if you know it. Even if you're stuck, DO NOT read for walkthroughs or whatever, because most of the time they will reveal the main plot of the story. I'm telling you this because I also checked for walkthroughs and they just spoilt the main thing that makes you understand the whole story before the end of the game.But this game is so epic that despite of the spoiler, it was still one of the greatest games I've ever played. Thank you George Lucas and Bioware.12/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2013
												This is a legacy Bioware Game created for Windows Xp and Xbox. 2003's Game of the Year. This is my all time favorite game. The only games I have played more are the timeless addictive multiplayer experiences of Halo 2 Xbox Live and World of Warcraft.Unsure if the GOG version runs better on modern operating systems. I own the Kotor Collection Released in 2012 by Lucas Arts for Microsoft Windows and it doesn't run any better than the steam version. I also owned it for Original Xbox which most of the time it ran flawlessly on that platform.In 2003 this game had impressive Visuals that really showcased the Xbox's hardware capabilities over the playstation 2. This Rpg was originally planned for Microsoft Windows in 2002 but got delayed and chosen to be an Xbox Exclusive.  This is the first Star Wars Franchise Game to delve into a new Era in the Expanded Universe: The old Republic Era thousands of years before A new Hope would take place. Yeah no Skywalker's here and this is an era where there are many Jedi and Dark Jedi. In this game your dropped into the middle of the Jedi Civil War that came almost immediately after the Mandalorian Wars. Heroes of the Republic have returned as conquerors. Many Jedi have been seduced by the dark side or killed in battle. The Republic's greatest hope is a young jedi named Bastila who has at an early age mastered Battle Meditation a powerful technique that allows the jedi to empower their allies and make their enemies lose the will to fight. Bastila and her companions must escape the outerim world of Taris and embark on a quest to Stop Darth Malak.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2012
												An amazing game from back in the early days of Bioware. The twist right near the end I never saw coming in that way Bioware have always been in great story telling. Apart from when they seemed to have become one with EA and messed things up, but I digress.Game starts where the republic ship you are on is under attack from Sith fighters and you have to make your way off the ship, battling your way through sith soldiers and getting to an escape pod where the real meat of the game begins on the planet of Taris.The game is based on the 3rd edition roleplaying game so if you have any experience with D&D you'll have no trouble getting into this game. As i said before, it's classic Bioware with the great storytelling and characters that are so realistic and you end up caring about. You get the chance to become either a Jedi or Sith. Both sides have different types of powers that can be used in many different ways. This is a game I highly recommend for it's story-line and replayability.

Posted: March 26, 2016
												Ridiculously overhyped but still worth your time.Kotor is your typical Bioware RPG, this time set in the rich Star Wars universe, albeit several millenia before the movies, hence the "old republic" title and here is my minor annoyances with this title begin. The atmosphere is dense and captures everything we like about Star Wars, likeable characters traversing colourful worlds but it never really does anything with the unfamiliar timeframe of the game. Every aspect of the gaming world is exactly like the Star Wars we already know, perfectly interchangeable, the planets are all too familiar and apparently the design of weapons, clothing etc didn't change inbetween Kotor and the movies. The people on Tatooine all live in the same huts like it's some kind of theme park. This may sound like a nitpick but I found the game never delivered on its promise of showing us the old republic, a new fragment in the Star Wars mosaic we know and love. This being said the worlds you are visiting will still get you hooked immediately, it's just a shame Bioware didn't do more with it. I know you have to tread carefully around golden calves but a bit more inspiration instead of trepidation would have been very welcome. Given some of the ridiculous content of the Expanded Universe I don't think Bioware could have screwed it up severely.Another aspect usually lauded that I found a bit lacking is the overarching storyline about Darth Revan. I don't want to spoil anything here but it doesn't go beyond cartoon badguy territory and in the end it's just a story about another Darth that wants to rule the galaxy and there's a shocking reveal about your character as well. Very safe, very standard. The story did the job alright but it's not as great as people make it out to be and I feel the need to clarify this for people who want to play Kotor and are being promised a shakespearean masterpiece. What story I did actually really enjoy and what I found the great strength of Kotor is the little stories that happen on the planets you visit. They all feel very alive and there's lots to discover and do. This is where I found my main enjoyment as you are given the perfect amount of freedom in how you can play your character. There are generally two extremes in RPG storytelling, either a basic linear progression of a character (which can work beautifully if done right) or complete freedom for the player which has the downside that you aren't playing an actual character with strengths, weaknesses, backstory, motivations because it's just a proxy for you to throw around in a big sandbox. Kotor falls comfortably in the middle. The dark/light graph at the bottom of your character screen does feel a bit outdated though and unfitting for a game where you can play comfortable in moral grey areas.The pseudo-turnbased combat does its job alright although I've seen it done better. As soon as the lightsabers arrive it gets somewhat tedious but never annoying. I know this is a game about Jedis and Siths but the mindset of the Prequel trilogy that Jedis have to use a lightsaber for everything from light gardening to cutting vegetables is what dragged down Star Wars so much over the last 15 years. In general a game well worth your time despite some flaws but it's not the second coming of christ that people make it out to be. Kotor is a well made above average RPG and for the current price an absolute steal.

Review in Progress; Will update as I progressThe Game / What I Like- RPG: A Role Playing Game :) Skill Points, Upgrades, Attributes, Experience, you get the picture (Skyrim, Fallout, Borderlands etc)- Classes: 3 Potential Classes (Stealth, Adventurer, Soldier) to choose from; Simple, Differentiated & Effective- Character Selection: The ability to customise your character attributes, or skip the process and use a quick creation featureFacts / Neutral- A Star Wars title- Lack of Steamworks Integration: Steam Achievements, Trading cards, etc- No Multiplayer- Runs well on Windows 8.1 (Intel HD 4000)- Camera Movement: Follows the older system, where movement and the camera are separate - Might be slightly tedious for some users (Personally - Pretty easy to get used)- Graphics: Looks pretty decent (Although there were games with better graphics at the time - e.g. GTA 3)My Cons- Tutorials: They lack creativity, could be more interactive (however, for a game released in 2003 - when tutorials were not as important a part, it seems alright)- Display: The display resolution only seems to go up to 1028 x 768 (NOTE: "Flawless Widescreen" fixes this issue)Purchased the Star Wars pack from Humble Bundle for $12; Enjoying the games thus far

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												I came into Knights of the Old Republic expecting very little. The combat at first seemed bland and the graphics unappealing (especially the player character). But as I got deeper and deeper into the web of dialogue choices and skilltrees I found a game that so surprised me with its beauty the character count would not allow me to express it all.The story begins 4,000 years before the rise of the Galactic Empire seen in the Star Wars films. It is a bold choice; to depart from the stock characters and scenes is to lose much of the iconic universe already known. But BioWare proves incredibly successful at creating a world of its own within the universe, delivering a story and atmosphere that would not be possible otherwise. I will not attempt to summarize it here- it is best recieved in its pure form.The game offers two main paths for the player: that of the light and dark side of the force. I myself chose to follow the light side, making decisions along the way that pushed me towards the light. I was never once truly tempted to choose the dark side, however, as the two paths become rather black-and-white, but that is the heritage of the Star Wars universe, and I could not imagine it anay other way.As for the combat, it takes place in a pausable real-time action-based system. Different abilities are gained by progressing through the skill tree of each character, called "Feats". These feats can be either direct upgrades to stats or abilities. I don't think it is much of a spoiler to say that the character is eventually allowed to utilize the force in a way similar to this, through a different tree. These abilities range from freezing an opponent (the ability I used the most) to choking them to death Vader-style. Equipment can also be customized, giving armor, damage resistance to different types of attacks, or reinforcing stats. All of these are available for every character in the game.Now to my favorite: the characters. I loved them. Every single one was beautifully crafted, and I couldn't help but care about all of them. The character is allowed different dialogue trees with every one, learning about them and their backstories. Unfortunately as party size is limited to three I was not able to spend time with each one as I would have liked, but I understand that the balance is needed. There is so much I want to say about every single one of them, but I want you to meet and fall in love with them by yourself.There is tons to do in each planet you visit, and I know for a fact I did not complete everything. Some adventures I didn't even find. Swoop-racing, pazaak (blackjack) playing, duelling are some of the blander activities. Others are best left for you to discover.I know that I'm biased as hell in favor of this game, but that's 'cause I absolutely love it. I would definitely recommend this game regardless of your prior experience with Star Wars, RPGs, or even videogames: at ten dollars, it delivers a game better than the sixty-dollar massive productions spewn out of most big publishers today. Get it.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2013
												This game is absolutely incredible. KOTOR is some of Bioware's finest work, and has yet to be rivaled. KOTOR is a must play for any Star wars fan, even if you don't like RPG's. It really captures the spirit of Star Wars as it tells the story of a brutal war set thousands of years before the Rebellion's struggle against the Empire. How you play is up to you. Do you take the path of the Light Side, or do you sucumb the allure of the Dark Side of the Force? And that's the beauty of Bioware's creations; you choose your own play style, *you* affect wether people live or die, and ultimately, the Republic itself.It should be noted, however, that while the combat system is fine, it may take some getting used to as KOTOR uses a dice roll system to decide things such as attack power, hits or misses, etc. which many modern games do not.KOTOR is a game that has more than stood the test of time, and ultimately become a classic that serves as a shining example of storytelling in videogames.Bottom-line: 5/5 Must Play. (And for the sale price often at or less than $5, playing this game really is a no-brainer.)

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Forget George Lucas's prequel trilogy, the best Star Wars story to take place before the events of A New Hope is Knights of the Old Republic. Of all the Star Wars games I have played over the years this is still head and shoulders above the rest, both in terms of gameplay and narrative.Prepare to spend the next 40 hours exploring the galaxy with Carth, Bastila, and the wonderfully sadistic, HK-47. Even for an RPG this old there is so much scope within the game. Before becoming a Jedi you can opt to be a solider, a scout, or a scoundrel like Han Solo. Each has its benefits and its pitfalls but the real fun is trying a new one every time and seeing which one best suits you.So as HK-47 would probably say, "statment: do yourselves a favour, meatbags, and buy this game". Although KOTOR II was a solid sequel, Knights of the Old Republic is still, not just the best entry in the series but, the best Star Wars game out there.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												This is my first time writing a review ever. I will first start out with how this is one of my favorite game titles from the sixth generation of console's. I was never a true Star Wars game or movie fan, sure I played some games like; star Wars BF 1&2, Star Wars Republic Commando which I would also recommend to any Star Wars fan. Now the KotoR series shows a deep connection not to the history made by George Lucas(not to discredid the man since I do not know how much he has contributed to the historical lore of his series) which the fanbase has mostly made for the accounting matters of most stories before and after the Star Wars Saga(all 6 movies). This Game was the second Star wars game I fell in love with after the first few hours of playing on the original Xbox. The mechanics were something I never really liked in most games and I admit I shrugged it off in terms of not wanting to play it since it went far off what I was used to for gameplay. The story, the Characters, the complete immersion of the destinies of people you interact with that could alter the fate of an entire planet quicker than you would have known of in a game like this. In short I really love this and KotoR II. Because of this game in particular, I have started down the evil path in all decision based games with a morality center like Jade Empire. then I just do everything different on the next playthrough. A lot of the game is laughable in today's sense of "Modern Gaming" or in the everything about the game's graphical engine and motor physics of the semi-turn-based combat which was as close to a then modern miracle/innovative as it could be at the time in "my" opinion. So yea, I will love and keep supporting games like these and if someone knows of more games like this just leave a msg at the end of the comment or msg my profile. 100/100 Don't mind the almost no play time on the thing, I have logged more than 80 on console

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												This is one the greatest games that I have ever played. I originally played KOTOR II on the original Xbox; it was one the best video game experiences I've ever had despite some of the issues with the game. Nearly 9 years later I started using steam and I noticed the KOTOR series on sale. I bought the two games and I must say that was the best decision I've made in a long time. Let me start off with a brief synopsis for those who are unaware of the story of KOTOR I. You essentially play a character with no background. Your first mission is to find a Jedi named Bastilla who was onboard the ship that you were on when it got attacked. Once you rescue her and escape with your new crew, you begin to learn the way of the Jedi on Dantooine. You get to choose the path you want to travel: the light side or the dark side. There is an evil sith lord named Malak who must be stopped, so you can either save the galaxy or become one of the most powerful sith lords. The choice is yours. Along the way you will befriend people and maybe lose them depending on your choices. Now I'm not going to go much more into the story; that is for you to discover dear reader.If you are a Star Wars fan, then get this. You can't call yourself a fan without having played this game. If you love RPGs, then get this game. Some issues are the d20 combat system that might seem unengaging and annoying at times. The story is a bit too black and white, but keep in mind that the Star Wars series in general has held a black and white morality viewpoint. This was just a minor issue for me because I had played KOTOR II before this game and it seemed to do a better job at making the morality of both the Jedi and the Sith greyish. The game might also seem a bit dated now, but trust me it holds up fairly well. The sheer mythology of Star Wars should be enough for you to buy this game. Even if you don't consider yourself a Star Wars fan, you will still enjoy this game. I hope this review answers any questions you had. Now I have a question for you: why are you wasting your time reading this when you should be playing KOTOR?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is both a fantastic RPG and a fantastic Star Wars game. BioWare excellently crafts meaningful outcomes for player decisions. This is mostly acheived through an accessible, yet deceptively deep combat system, beautiful character design and execution, imaginative world-building, and interesting dialogue trees. Role-playing as either a light, gray, or dark jedi delivers unique and fulfilling gameplay that stays true to the greater Star Wars lore. It really is a shame that so much Star Wars media from this time period has been declared non-canon, since SW:KoTOR's themes and stories really do pay respect to and benefit Lucas' original Star Wars. I should this game isn't for everybody. While it does deliver fun RPG gameplay for RPG fans and awesome Star Wars content for Star Wars fans, audiences outside these two sets might find issue with much of the game's offerings. The game is suspect to many of age-old issues with classic RPGs: points of no return, difficulty spikes, and unclear combat specs. Graphically speaking, the game holds up fine, but some animations and textures can be a bit jarring at times. The game's native aspect-ratio was developed with XBOX consoles in mind back in 2003, so displaying current PC monitor resoltions won't scale the game to the whole screen. That said, the game's general art design does make the low-res pill easier to swallow.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Personal rating: 10/10Replayability: MediumBudget: Worth it, unless you dislike Star Wars severely. Lenght: A few days to a week. KOTOR is one of the best roleplaying games I've ever played. Apart from the infuriatingly ugly jedi robes in this game, this might be one of the best titles ever. Another thing that I should point out as a serious mistake from the developers side, is that you can only have 3 active party members at a time. Instead of such a set up, I'd have preferred if encounters were just that much harder, and you'd need all 9 or however many party members it is you have. Many party members end up just being "extras" in the story, only taken out for air when you realize it's been a while, and you need to level them up, and possibly unlock some dialogue with them. Many other games pull the same stunt, such as Dragon Age or Mass Effect, and it's equally silly. If you have the man-power, use it!. Apart from that, this game, being a Star Wars game, dives head first into the lore and setting for Star Wars and introduces villains and heroes that can compete with the heroes from the original trilogy. The plot of the story is, I'd say, even better than that of the original movies, and much more immersive. Gameplay wise, the game is very similar to dragon age origins. Any Star Wars fan should play this game. Any RPG fan should play this game and become a star wars fan.

If you like RPGs and/or the Star Wars universe you will surely enjoy it.++ ++ ATTENTION!! ++ ++In the Steam version of this game I have encountered a major annoying issue. The game kept crashing on startup, perhaps due to the Steam overlay or the video scenes, maybe both (yeah, we all know Steam is evil because it has Gremlins inside..). This seems to be a common problem among old games being rebooted on Steam, and there are fixes around the forums - one just needs to look out for them. I know, it's annoying to do that. Not to mention that the current fixes for this specific game  force you to skip cutscenes, making you regrettably lose a good part of entertainment. :(But, imho,  that's not a good excuse not to play this game. It's sheer fun makes it worth all the time you may spend on it, the storyline is great, nicely made and full of surprises, making this one of the best games I've ever played no matter the issues.Regarding the problems, I either suggest looking for fixes peeking on the forums (Google will always be your friend) or finding the standalone version, because this game is worthy of being played.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Overall, I would rate KotOR 8/10 and most definetely one of the greatest RPG titles out there!  Knights of the Old Republic focuses on the span of time after the Mandalorian Wars of the Old Republic, and follows a soldier with little recollection of their past.  The graphics are pretty well done, best enchanced with mods (I have tons of awesome mods on mine that add in content and bring in hd graphics), the gameplay is simple and well executed, and the storyline is a great one to add to your Star Wars repitoee (sp?)  There are some things that sort of get left behind for your character, such as melee weapons and ranged weapons and combative skills that go with them once you become a Jedi (or Sith if that's what you want to role-play) however they still help your companions.  The companion system is great, allowing either 0,1, or 2 companions - be sure to check with all of them for specific content related to your companions!  One game-breaking bug that should be mentioned... try to do Tattoine last if at all possible.  There is a companion mission that leads you to tatooine that gets broken if you have gone to particular places before getting the quest - I could provide more info but that would be a spoiler.  Pick up this great game and have fun!

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												*Disclaimer: This is not nostalgia speaking because the first time i ever played this game as ealier this year.*Many consider KOTOR 1 to be a jewel of the star war games, and i would have to agree i have played many of the star war games and this is the absolute best out of any. Now before you ♥♥♥♥♥ about the graphics ( and i know you are doing it as you read this ) suck on your COD pacifier and calm down enough to listen to reason, this game was made in 2003 or around there; not everyone is going to look like a perferct reproduction of the producers fat roll. Next up is the story line ( yes thats all I had to say about the graphics now shut up and suck on your COD pacifier ) the story line is golden and a prime example of how a star wars game should be written, not like force unleashed, and i am sorry if you really like that game but it has a god awfull story line. The combat, is actually turn based if you notice you take turns slapping each other with giant glow sticks instead of going into full out battle to the death like in the movies. Another thing that makes this game a absolute jewel is the fact that it seems to be clear of bugs unless you mod it to hell. As for my closing statement all i have to say is i feel sorry for hardcore star wars fans, the franchise has been really crappy in the recent years. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												This game is awesome. It is extremely enjoyable. This isn't because it has "stellar graphics" or "hd audio". It's because of its story.The game itself plays like a movie, where there is constant interaction between characters, and choices that can change the course of the story. There's endless battles, and dangerous situations lurking around every corner where you have to choose what you would do in a situation. As well as puzzles and other things to get you thinking which (in my opinion) is much more enjoyable than all "point and shoot" games that you see today. Another thing that I enjoyed about this game was all the Star Wars lore that you see throughout the game. Some that is completely new and stunning, and some that relates somewhat to the Star Wars movies (which occur a very long time after the events of this game). And you always be encountering new species of aliens, and other familiar species that you know you've seen before in Star Wars as well.The only things I found confusing in this game were the battles within the game, which took some getting used to, and once I did, I was able to enjoy the game with no problem at all. So if you enjoy Role-Playing, and Star Wars, then this is most definitely the game for you.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												I first played this game when I was ~17 and it was amazing and it still is to this day.  While the graphics are obviously dated it takes nothing away from the masterpiece that this game is.  If you like Star Wars or not if you like RPGs you want to play this game if you haven't.The gameplay is based on d20 role-playing game system.  You can pick your class and your skills.  Force powers are yours to choose.  There are different endings based on your choices as well.  The characters, THE CHARACTERS.  George Lucas wishes this was one of his prequel movies.  The chracters in this game are fantastic.  They don't need to make the story but the fact that they're good makes it an even better overall game.MODS!  There are a lot of mods out there as well.  You can get different lightsabre colors, different clothes for your characters, you can change it up a lot from the original game.Command: Play this game, meatbag.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												This is one the greatest games that I have ever played. I originally played KOTOR II on the original Xbox; it was one the best video game experiences I've ever had despite some of the issues with the game. Nearly 9 years later I started using steam and I noticed the KOTOR series on sale. I bought the two games and I must say that was the best decision I've made in a long time. Let me start off with a brief synopsis for those who are unaware of the story of KOTOR I. You essentially play a character with no background. Your first mission is to find a Jedi named Bastilla who was onboard the ship that you were on when it got attacked. Once you rescue her and escape with your new crew, you begin to learn the way of the Jedi on Dantooine. You get to choose the path you want to travel: the light side or the dark side. There is an evil sith lord named Malak who must be stopped, so you can either save the galaxy or become one of the most powerful sith lords. The choice is yours. Along the way you will befriend people and maybe lose them depending on your choices. Now I'm not going to go much more into the story; that is for you to discover dear reader.If you are a Star Wars fan, then get this. You can't call yourself a fan without having played this game. If you love RPGs, then get this game. Some issues are the d20 combat system that might seem unengaging and annoying at times. The story is a bit too black and white, but keep in mind that the Star Wars series in general has held a black and white morality viewpoint. This was just a minor issue for me because I had played KOTOR II before this game and it seemed to do a better job at making the morality of both the Jedi and the Sith greyish. The game might also seem a bit dated now, but trust me it holds up fairly well. The sheer mythology of Star Wars should be enough for you to buy this game. Even if you don't consider yourself a Star Wars fan, you will still enjoy this game. I hope this review answers any questions you had. Now I have a question for you: why are you wasting your time reading this when you should be playing KOTOR?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is both a fantastic RPG and a fantastic Star Wars game. BioWare excellently crafts meaningful outcomes for player decisions. This is mostly acheived through an accessible, yet deceptively deep combat system, beautiful character design and execution, imaginative world-building, and interesting dialogue trees. Role-playing as either a light, gray, or dark jedi delivers unique and fulfilling gameplay that stays true to the greater Star Wars lore. It really is a shame that so much Star Wars media from this time period has been declared non-canon, since SW:KoTOR's themes and stories really do pay respect to and benefit Lucas' original Star Wars. I should this game isn't for everybody. While it does deliver fun RPG gameplay for RPG fans and awesome Star Wars content for Star Wars fans, audiences outside these two sets might find issue with much of the game's offerings. The game is suspect to many of age-old issues with classic RPGs: points of no return, difficulty spikes, and unclear combat specs. Graphically speaking, the game holds up fine, but some animations and textures can be a bit jarring at times. The game's native aspect-ratio was developed with XBOX consoles in mind back in 2003, so displaying current PC monitor resoltions won't scale the game to the whole screen. That said, the game's general art design does make the low-res pill easier to swallow.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Personal rating: 10/10Replayability: MediumBudget: Worth it, unless you dislike Star Wars severely. Lenght: A few days to a week. KOTOR is one of the best roleplaying games I've ever played. Apart from the infuriatingly ugly jedi robes in this game, this might be one of the best titles ever. Another thing that I should point out as a serious mistake from the developers side, is that you can only have 3 active party members at a time. Instead of such a set up, I'd have preferred if encounters were just that much harder, and you'd need all 9 or however many party members it is you have. Many party members end up just being "extras" in the story, only taken out for air when you realize it's been a while, and you need to level them up, and possibly unlock some dialogue with them. Many other games pull the same stunt, such as Dragon Age or Mass Effect, and it's equally silly. If you have the man-power, use it!. Apart from that, this game, being a Star Wars game, dives head first into the lore and setting for Star Wars and introduces villains and heroes that can compete with the heroes from the original trilogy. The plot of the story is, I'd say, even better than that of the original movies, and much more immersive. Gameplay wise, the game is very similar to dragon age origins. Any Star Wars fan should play this game. Any RPG fan should play this game and become a star wars fan.

Posted: September 7, 2014
												This one is a GREAT game. If you like RPGs and/or the Star Wars universe you will surely enjoy it.++ ++ ATTENTION!! ++ ++In the Steam version of this game I have encountered a major annoying issue. The game kept crashing on startup, perhaps due to the Steam overlay or the video scenes, maybe both (yeah, we all know Steam is evil because it has Gremlins inside..). This seems to be a common problem among old games being rebooted on Steam, and there are fixes around the forums - one just needs to look out for them. I know, it's annoying to do that. Not to mention that the current fixes for this specific game  force you to skip cutscenes, making you regrettably lose a good part of entertainment. :(But, imho,  that's not a good excuse not to play this game. It's sheer fun makes it worth all the time you may spend on it, the storyline is great, nicely made and full of surprises, making this one of the best games I've ever played no matter the issues.Regarding the problems, I either suggest looking for fixes peeking on the forums (Google will always be your friend) or finding the standalone version, because this game is worthy of being played.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												It's an old game for sure, but it's one of the better SP RPGs out there. It gives you freedom of choice in many circumstances, you can forge or destroy the relationships with your companions...and much more.It is even possible to go full dark side and change the outcome of the game. All in all it's stuff you want from an RPG.Exploration, freedom and a good story with great and annoying characters.However, of course this being a Bioware game, it has numerous bugs, from pathing to movement to quests not being completable, etc. It's what you would expect from this developer, which is pretty sad. And this happens with every Bioware game -.- One would think they would learn.Apart from that, obviously the game is extremely old. While it does even run on a Win 10 machine and looks rather ok, it does not support HD resolutions, the animations are rather clunky (but the combat is great) and the UI is ATROCIOUS. Inventory management is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ If you can bear with all of that you will still find yourself a solid game, even after all this time, but be prepared to make some adjustments...

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Forget George Lucas's prequel trilogy, the best Star Wars story to take place before the events of A New Hope is Knights of the Old Republic. Of all the Star Wars games I have played over the years this is still head and shoulders above the rest, both in terms of gameplay and narrative.Prepare to spend the next 40 hours exploring the galaxy with Carth, Bastila, and the wonderfully sadistic, HK-47. Even for an RPG this old there is so much scope within the game. Before becoming a Jedi you can opt to be a solider, a scout, or a scoundrel like Han Solo. Each has its benefits and its pitfalls but the real fun is trying a new one every time and seeing which one best suits you.So as HK-47 would probably say, "statment: do yourselves a favour, meatbags, and buy this game". Although KOTOR II was a solid sequel, Knights of the Old Republic is still, not just the best entry in the series but, the best Star Wars game out there.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												This is my first time writing a review ever. I will first start out with how this is one of my favorite game titles from the sixth generation of console's. I was never a true Star Wars game or movie fan, sure I played some games like; star Wars BF 1&2, Star Wars Republic Commando which I would also recommend to any Star Wars fan. Now the KotoR series shows a deep connection not to the history made by George Lucas(not to discredid the man since I do not know how much he has contributed to the historical lore of his series) which the fanbase has mostly made for the accounting matters of most stories before and after the Star Wars Saga(all 6 movies). This Game was the second Star wars game I fell in love with after the first few hours of playing on the original Xbox. The mechanics were something I never really liked in most games and I admit I shrugged it off in terms of not wanting to play it since it went far off what I was used to for gameplay. The story, the Characters, the complete immersion of the destinies of people you interact with that could alter the fate of an entire planet quicker than you would have known of in a game like this. In short I really love this and KotoR II. Because of this game in particular, I have started down the evil path in all decision based games with a morality center like Jade Empire. then I just do everything different on the next playthrough. A lot of the game is laughable in today's sense of "Modern Gaming" or in the everything about the game's graphical engine and motor physics of the semi-turn-based combat which was as close to a then modern miracle/innovative as it could be at the time in "my" opinion. So yea, I will love and keep supporting games like these and if someone knows of more games like this just leave a msg at the end of the comment or msg my profile. 100/100 Don't mind the almost no play time on the thing, I have logged more than 80 on console

The Game I Spent Hours Exploring In My Younger DaysWow. When I was younger I was given this game. New to the RPG genre at the time, I played about 5 minutes and basically hated it. About a month later I decided to pick it back up. BEST DESCISION EVER. This game shaped what modern RPGs are. This game looked beautiful when it was new, and I had never seen anything like the massive amount of content inside it before. It was exactly as I remembered, and when I get some time, I'll sit down and play through a couple times. Of course I'll have to check absolutely every container and do every quest, but that's the great part.Good for nostalgia, or if you are craving a new adventure, you won't be dissapointed. 17/5

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												This is my number one game of all time, and I definitely don't say that lightly. I may not have a huge amount of hours on this, but that's only because I played this so much before it was on Steam. It's not perfect, but then no game is without faults. I love everything about the Star Wars expanded universe and this is the pinnacle of it, it rises high above the waste and filth that are 90% of Star Wars video games and stands proudly as an amazing story drive experience. Light Side or Dark side, you choose, it's all up to you and it will affect you're ending and which of your party members decide to stand with you.I'm not normally a fan of turn based combat, but they nailed it right here, the animations, the visuals and the effectsdo look quite dated now but believe me, at the time it was a sight to behold.It's hard to give this a neutral critical review because it would be like insulting my child if I were to say too many negative things against it. I cannot recommend this game enough. BUY IT WHATEVER THE PRICEPlus it has one of my favourite WTF moments in gaming.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												It's an old game for sure, but it's one of the better SP RPGs out there. It gives you freedom of choice in many circumstances, you can forge or destroy the relationships with your companions...and much more.It is even possible to go full dark side and change the outcome of the game. All in all it's stuff you want from an RPG.Exploration, freedom and a good story with great and annoying characters.However, of course this being a Bioware game, it has numerous bugs, from pathing to movement to quests not being completable, etc. It's what you would expect from this developer, which is pretty sad. And this happens with every Bioware game -.- One would think they would learn.Apart from that, obviously the game is extremely old. While it does even run on a Win 10 machine and looks rather ok, it does not support HD resolutions, the animations are rather clunky (but the combat is great) and the UI is ATROCIOUS. Inventory management is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ If you can bear with all of that you will still find yourself a solid game, even after all this time, but be prepared to make some adjustments...

Review in Progress; Will update as I progressThe Game / What I Like- RPG: A Role Playing Game :) Skill Points, Upgrades, Attributes, Experience, you get the picture (Skyrim, Fallout, Borderlands etc)- Classes: 3 Potential Classes (Stealth, Adventurer, Soldier) to choose from; Simple, Differentiated & Effective- Character Selection: The ability to customise your character attributes, or skip the process and use a quick creation featureFacts / Neutral- A Star Wars title- Lack of Steamworks Integration: Steam Achievements, Trading cards, etc- No Multiplayer- Runs well on Windows 8.1 (Intel HD 4000)- Camera Movement: Follows the older system, where movement and the camera are separate - Might be slightly tedious for some users (Personally - Pretty easy to get used)- Graphics: Looks pretty decent (Although there were games with better graphics at the time - e.g. GTA 3)My Cons- Tutorials: They lack creativity, could be more interactive (however, for a game released in 2003 - when tutorials were not as important a part, it seems alright)- Display: The display resolution only seems to go up to 1028 x 768 (NOTE: "Flawless Widescreen" fixes this issue)Purchased the Star Wars pack from Humble Bundle for $12; Enjoying the games thus far

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												Ridiculously overhyped but still worth your time.Kotor is your typical Bioware RPG, this time set in the rich Star Wars universe, albeit several millenia before the movies, hence the "old republic" title and here is my minor annoyances with this title begin. The atmosphere is dense and captures everything we like about Star Wars, likeable characters traversing colourful worlds but it never really does anything with the unfamiliar timeframe of the game. Every aspect of the gaming world is exactly like the Star Wars we already know, perfectly interchangeable, the planets are all too familiar and apparently the design of weapons, clothing etc didn't change inbetween Kotor and the movies. The people on Tatooine all live in the same huts like it's some kind of theme park. This may sound like a nitpick but I found the game never delivered on its promise of showing us the old republic, a new fragment in the Star Wars mosaic we know and love. This being said the worlds you are visiting will still get you hooked immediately, it's just a shame Bioware didn't do more with it. I know you have to tread carefully around golden calves but a bit more inspiration instead of trepidation would have been very welcome. Given some of the ridiculous content of the Expanded Universe I don't think Bioware could have screwed it up severely.Another aspect usually lauded that I found a bit lacking is the overarching storyline about Darth Revan. I don't want to spoil anything here but it doesn't go beyond cartoon badguy territory and in the end it's just a story about another Darth that wants to rule the galaxy and there's a shocking reveal about your character as well. Very safe, very standard. The story did the job alright but it's not as great as people make it out to be and I feel the need to clarify this for people who want to play Kotor and are being promised a shakespearean masterpiece. What story I did actually really enjoy and what I found the great strength of Kotor is the little stories that happen on the planets you visit. They all feel very alive and there's lots to discover and do. This is where I found my main enjoyment as you are given the perfect amount of freedom in how you can play your character. There are generally two extremes in RPG storytelling, either a basic linear progression of a character (which can work beautifully if done right) or complete freedom for the player which has the downside that you aren't playing an actual character with strengths, weaknesses, backstory, motivations because it's just a proxy for you to throw around in a big sandbox. Kotor falls comfortably in the middle. The dark/light graph at the bottom of your character screen does feel a bit outdated though and unfitting for a game where you can play comfortable in moral grey areas.The pseudo-turnbased combat does its job alright although I've seen it done better. As soon as the lightsabers arrive it gets somewhat tedious but never annoying. I know this is a game about Jedis and Siths but the mindset of the Prequel trilogy that Jedis have to use a lightsaber for everything from light gardening to cutting vegetables is what dragged down Star Wars so much over the last 15 years. In general a game well worth your time despite some flaws but it's not the second coming of christ that people make it out to be. Kotor is a well made above average RPG and for the current price an absolute steal.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2013
												I hate the party mechanics in Bioware games. I HATE them. I have never had more difficulty getting my characters to just freaking do what I tell tham to do than I have in Bioware games. If I tell you to attack enemy A, then FREAKING ATTACK ENEMY A. I don't give a crispy flaming crap if you think enemy B would be a better target. Attack enemy A! Also, don't stand there like a retard waiting for your attack to cooldown before you even start to close the distance to the next enemy! To that same effect, don't cancel the attacks I queued up for you if I get sick of you standing around, and manually move you myself.I honestly can't figure out whether the game wants me to sit back and more or less "manage" my party, or whether it needs me to micromanage, and pick every single move and attack for all my party members all the time. It sure feels like they couldn't find their way out of a bathroom without my help, even though they fight my orders at every turn.I swear I'm going to skip all future Bioware games. The idiotic party-control mechanics ALWAYS get in the way of otherwise fantastic games.Also, this moronic game design choice of throwing insanely overpowered enemies randomly in with ridiculously weak ones has GOT to stop!! Who EVER thinks that that's fun? No joke, I just got done fending off 3 waves of 4 sand people each with no rest in between (and no grenades, stimulants, repair kits, or medpacks either), and 30 footsteps later, I come across 3 sand people (1 holy man and 2 elites) that absolutely and utterly annihilate my entire party within 15 seconds. I focus my entire party's attacks, and can't even kill one. I throw 9 grenades (2 concussion to stun the enemies, and then 7 frag), and can still barely manage to kill one. I turn the difficulty down to easy, and am STILL not able to kill more than one of them.Difficulty spikes I can understand, but this is difficulty impossible. I literally could not even come CLOSE to killing that group, no matter what I tried, after at least 20 attempts. Some people say to not explore into the desert, but that's stupid. Who designs a (pretend-to-be) open world game, then completely prevents players from leaving the beaten path? I was hardly 10 steps off the path anyway. Other people say "just leave and come back later," but that's stupid too. There is literally no reason at all for (what many consider to be) the toughest enemies in the entire game randomly placed in the midst of weakling nobodies, on the first visited planet!Tattooine is widely regarded as the first (sometimes second) planet to go to, so clearly I'm doing something wrong. I don't freaking care what it is though, as this game has♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off unbelieveably bad.Instant delete, will never play again. How do people enjoy this crap?

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												I came into Knights of the Old Republic expecting very little. The combat at first seemed bland and the graphics unappealing (especially the player character). But as I got deeper and deeper into the web of dialogue choices and skilltrees I found a game that so surprised me with its beauty the character count would not allow me to express it all.The story begins 4,000 years before the rise of the Galactic Empire seen in the Star Wars films. It is a bold choice; to depart from the stock characters and scenes is to lose much of the iconic universe already known. But BioWare proves incredibly successful at creating a world of its own within the universe, delivering a story and atmosphere that would not be possible otherwise. I will not attempt to summarize it here- it is best recieved in its pure form.The game offers two main paths for the player: that of the light and dark side of the force. I myself chose to follow the light side, making decisions along the way that pushed me towards the light. I was never once truly tempted to choose the dark side, however, as the two paths become rather black-and-white, but that is the heritage of the Star Wars universe, and I could not imagine it anay other way.As for the combat, it takes place in a pausable real-time action-based system. Different abilities are gained by progressing through the skill tree of each character, called "Feats". These feats can be either direct upgrades to stats or abilities. I don't think it is much of a spoiler to say that the character is eventually allowed to utilize the force in a way similar to this, through a different tree. These abilities range from freezing an opponent (the ability I used the most) to choking them to death Vader-style. Equipment can also be customized, giving armor, damage resistance to different types of attacks, or reinforcing stats. All of these are available for every character in the game.Now to my favorite: the characters. I loved them. Every single one was beautifully crafted, and I couldn't help but care about all of them. The character is allowed different dialogue trees with every one, learning about them and their backstories. Unfortunately as party size is limited to three I was not able to spend time with each one as I would have liked, but I understand that the balance is needed. There is so much I want to say about every single one of them, but I want you to meet and fall in love with them by yourself.There is tons to do in each planet you visit, and I know for a fact I did not complete everything. Some adventures I didn't even find. Swoop-racing, pazaak (blackjack) playing, duelling are some of the blander activities. Others are best left for you to discover.I know that I'm biased as hell in favor of this game, but that's 'cause I absolutely love it. I would definitely recommend this game regardless of your prior experience with Star Wars, RPGs, or even videogames: at ten dollars, it delivers a game better than the sixty-dollar massive productions spewn out of most big publishers today. Get it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												I hold Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic in the highest respect and I recommend this game to anyone interested in a very different Star Wars story. Set four thousand years before the Star Wars trilogies, KOTOR takes you on a mysterious journey of a Republic soldier who is given the mission to find and protect a Jedi named Bastila from the Sith Empire. You will meet unique and dynamic characters as you travel through the galaxy and you will amass a team composed of a decorated pilot, jedi, a scoundrel, a droid, and even a wookie. The story is dynamic and the music is fitting for the era.This game has a ton of different scenarios in which you can play out your own way. KOTOR is replayable and you can choose to travel the light side or dark side. You will not regret getting this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												I always liked this game.  The story, although typical star wars fare, has a plot twist that drives the story nicely.  The recruitable party members are mostly interesting.  Some of the locations are pretty cool.  As a D20 based rpg (pausable) It is a nice transition between pure point and click and OTS 3rd action rpg.  You hold left mouse to walk and turn with the mouse.  The camera sticks to 1 axis, there is no looking up or down, so a controller is NOT necessary.  Graphically, The game looks great for a 12 year old game (2/1/15 review date).  I have the xbox version, and recently started a playthru on my 360 with it.  I bought this version so I could play on my laptop, and to A/B the 2 is night and day.  I played thru this unmodded.  It looks fine in 4:3, the way it was coded.  The widescreen mods just stretch it and shrink the ui to an almost unusable size.  My complaints about the game are that is it shorter than many other CRPGs content wise.  I feel the sidequests were limited.  Also, some of the backgrounds are bad.  The first world, taris, is a bland world where every room looks the same.  The explorable areas are limited in scope, even moreso than they actually are.  What I mean is there are little to no secrets.  If you are in a huge area, and nothing lights up as clickable, don't bother running around to the edges.  Fog of War clearing to find secrets is fun for me, but not in this game.  Although you are allowed to do quests in any order mostly, and visit the planets in any order the game still feels like it is on rails.  Also, the light/dark choices are not very ambiguous.  Very black and white with little grey.With that said, there are some bright spots in the questing and dialogue.  After all, this is a bioware rpg.  It is definitely worth a playthru.  I am going thru my collection of crpgs playing thru, so it is up against stiff competition in my recent memory is all.  I have a windows 7 64 pro Nvidia gtx765m system.  The game ran fine.  I didn't get my first crash until 40 hours in while loading a movie.  All in all, in a 48 hour playthru, I had 2 crashes. There are some issues with newer systems than have been reported.  It isn't a win 7 issue, or all win 7 systems would need to work at it to get it to run, which is not the case.  If you aren't good at computers or don't know what apps your rig is running in the background, maybe wait till a sale just in case.  Remember, the whining on the forums is the minoroty.  Every person who can't get it to run goes online to complain.  The many, many who run it fine do not go online to claim how it works well.  The game has a few bugs (uncompleteable quests etc..), but nothing I found game breaking.  In any RPG with branching questlines, save often, multiple spots.  Even if you play roguelike and dont save load, having a backup in case of a bug or glitch makes the blood pressure go down.All in all, a very solid modern crpg.  One of the last before they all went the way of skyrim (a fine game, but some of us rpg players dont want to button mash.  We like winning combat thru tactics, char building, and gear. )  I personally prefer  KOTOR 2 atmosphere wise, but this isn't too far behind .

content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												The original Knights of the Old Republic was a classic, and an icon for the karma based RPG genera, which I would have highly recommend for anyone looking for a good RPG where your choices actually mattered. However, with that said, it has aged terribly, in fact, it has aged worse than most games made in the late 1980’s and that is a serious statement. Just trying to get it to play on Windows 7, which will soon (from the time of writing this) no longer even be supported, took a bit of work. Trying to get it to play in Windows 10 is about as fun as unskipable cut scenes (which thankful, this game doesn’t have many of- hint it’s the space bar). However, getting it to run on a modern OS isn’t the game’s main issue, it’s getting it to run on modern monitors. This damn game, even though it came out after wide screen monitors were already a common thing, does not support wide screen resolutions, forget about HD resolutions. So unless you plan on playing this on an old square low res CRT monitor (and yes, by the time this game came out both widescreen and highres CRT monitors were also very common) to get it to run in widescreen you will need to pull out your hair before you get it to play properly. If you want to play it in HD Widescreen on a modern OS, have fun, I’ve spent more time trying to get the damn game to work than I did replaying it. If you’re a masochist you should use this patch: http://www.wsgf.org/article/star-wars-knights-old-republic. At the end of the day there are millions of PC games, thousands of which are really good games worth playing, half of which are probably better than this game, and I own hundreds of them, and I still haven’t played them all. So this is a final goodbye to a game I used to love. I will never play SWKOTOR again, and that is a little sad because like Morrowind (which has aged wonderfully and I highly recommend) it was a game I constantly want to replay, but unlike Morrowind, I can’t do it without spending more time trying to get it to launch than I would spend actually playing in any given session. This came has caused me so much anger and frustration I am giving up. My recommendation, if you have a life and value your time, don’t bother. Go find another game which you will be able to enjoy without wanting to shout from the top of your lungs for hours on end- before you even spend a single minute actually playing.

												I really want to love this game, but I just can't.Don't get me wrong - it's a fantastic game, especially for one that's thirteen years old -  cool story, interesting characters, open-ended dialogue that impacts the story; but the combat system is about as fun and interesting as watching paint dry while listening to your grandfather's war tales and sitting a geography exam at the same time.I came into this game expecting the amazing, critically-acclaimed masterpiece that so many people rave about, perhaps reminiscent of The Force Unleashed with a non-linear story, but alas, no, I got to click a couple buttons to decide what and how to attack, watched my character slash his weapon about the place, and then take some damage.If you are a huge fan of dice-rolling RPG's, I would highly recommend this game, otherwise, keep your credit card in your wallet.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												This could be a really good game. It has all it needs for that. A great, deep story. The original alien languages and soundtracks. An upgrade system for your stuff that is fun to play with and try different combinations, lots of weapons and even more items. Even the graphics look nice so many years after its release.BUT... it is a game from 2003 - for Windows XP. It has some severe technical issues on modern computers and with the newer windows. I used Windows 7 and I barely got it to work. It needed a lot of tweaking and unchecking options, graphic menus and so on until it would actually start without crashing. Even then you would have missing textures here and there in the game.It also had some lags from time to time. Which means it "froze" for up to 30 seconds before it continued.I could live with that. For 20 hours I had a good time with the game and the story. Then I reached the second planet and it crashed. Repeatedly. At exact the same place: When it played a specific video sequence. A quick look into the steam forums of the game confirmed my fears: Pages full of people asking for help because of game crashes. I guess I was lucky that I could play it as long as I did.But I don't think that one would like to spend many hours in this game just to get kicked out when it starts to get interesting. I for once was quite disappointed. So by all means, I can't recommend it.
